longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: To consolidate and amend the law relating to immigration and deportation.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title
section.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Immigration Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this Ordinance, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: adjudicator (審裁員) means the chief adjudicator, deputy chief adjudicator and any other adjudicator appointed under section 53F; (Added 62 of 1980 s. 2. Amended 24 of 1984 s. 2)

def.name: APECBusinessTravelCard
def.leadIn: APEC business travel card (亞太經合組織商務旅遊證) means a document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: issued by—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Director of Immigration; or

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.leadIn: of a place outside Hong Kong which is—

subparagraph.name: I
II
subparagraph.content: recognized in writing by the Director of Immigration for the purposes of this definition; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.leadIn: who is, in relation to that place—

subparagraph.name: I
subparagraph.content: equivalent to the Director of Immigration; or

subparagraph.name: II
subparagraph.content: accepted in writing by the Director of Immigration as the person who may issue the document; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: which enables the holder of the document—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: if the document is issued by the person referred to in paragraph (a)(ii), to enter Hong Kong as a visitor without a visa; (Added 6 of 1999 s. 2)

subsection.def: approved immigration anchorage (入境船隻認可碇泊處) means a place designated as an approved immigration anchorage by order under section 60;
approved landing place (認可着陸地點) means a place designated as an approved landing place by order under section 60;
Board (委員會) means a Refugee Status Review Board established under section 13G; (Added 23 of 1989 s. 2)

certificate of entitlement (居留權證明書) means a Certificate of Entitlement to the Right of Abode in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region issued under section 2AB(6)(a) and includes a certified duplicate issued under section 2AC(6)(a); (Added 124 of 1997 s. 2)

certificate of identity (身分證明書) means a document, other than a document of identity, which is issued by the Director of Immigration for the purpose of international travel to a person who is not the holder of, and is unable to obtain, a valid travel document; (Added 66 of 1981 s. 2)
child (子女), for the purposes of Part IIIA, means a legitimate or legitimated child, a stepchild and a child adopted in a manner recognized by law; (Amended 122 of 1997 s. 2)
Commissioner of Registration (人事登記處處長) has the same meaning as it has in the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); (Replaced 31 of 1987 s. 2)

crew (全體船員、全體機員), in relation to a ship or aircraft, means all persons actually employed in the working or service of the ship or aircraft, including the captain, and member of the crew (船員、機員) shall be construed accordingly;
deportation order (遞解離境令) means an order under section 20;
detention centre (羈留中心) means any place designated under section 13H as a detention centre; (Added 53 of 1989 s. 2)
detention warrant (羈留令) means a warrant issued under section 29(1) or (2);

Director (處長) means the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration, any assistant director of immigration and any member of the Immigration Service of the rank of senior principal immigration officer; (Replaced 82 of 1993 s. 2)

document of identity (簽證身分書) means a document issued by the Director of Immigration for the purpose of visa endorsement to a person who is not the holder of, and is unable to obtain, a valid travel document; (Added 66 of 1981 s. 2)
entry permit (入境證) means an entry permit issued under this Ordinance;
examination (訊問) includes a further examination under section 4(1), and examine (訊問) shall be construed accordingly;

HKSAR passport (特區護照) means a Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Passport issued under section 3 of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Passports Ordinance (Cap. 539); (Added 124 of 1997 s. 2. Amended 127 of 1997 s. 13)
Hong Kong permanent resident (香港永久性居民) means a person who belongs to a class or description of persons specified in Schedule 1; (Added 31 of 1987 s. 2)
identity card (身分證) has the same meaning as it has in the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); (Replaced 31 of 1987 s. 2)
immigrant (入境者) means a person who is not a Hong Kong permanent resident; (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 2)

immigration assistant (入境事務助理員) means any member of the Immigration Service of the rank of chief immigration assistant, senior immigration assistant or immigration assistant; (Added 57 of 1972 s. 2. Amended 42 of 1979 s. 2; 65 of 1989 s. 2)
immigration officer (入境事務主任) means any member of the Immigration Service of or above the rank of assistant immigration officer;

def.name: Land
def.leadIn: land (入境) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter by land or disembark from a ship or aircraft; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a person who arrives in Hong Kong otherwise than by land or in a ship or aircraft, land in Hong Kong;

subsection.def: limit of stay (逗留期限) means a condition of stay limiting the period during which a person may remain in Hong Kong;

def.name: Owner
def.leadIn: owner (擁有人) includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a ship or aircraft, any charterer to whom the ship or aircraft is demised;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to a vehicle—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any person in whose name the vehicle is registered under the Road Traffic Ordinance (Cap. 374);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any person by whom the vehicle is kept and used; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if it is the subject of a hiring agreement or hire purchase agreement, the person in possession of the vehicle under the agreement; (Replaced 61 of 1986 s. 2)

subsection.def: permanent identity card (永久性居民身分證) has the same meaning as it has in the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); (Added 124 of 1997 s. 2)

prescribed Central People’s Government travel document (訂明的中央人民政府旅行證件) means a travel permit issued by the Central People’s Government which on its cover is called “因公往来香港澳门特别行政区通行证” and which bears an endorsement stating that “持证人系国家公职人员，受委派在香港、澳门特别行政区工作。”; (Added 31 of 2002 s. 2)
re-entry permit (回港證) means a re-entry permit issued under this Ordinance;
refugee centre (難民中心) means any place designated under section 13C as a refugee centre; (Added 35 of 1981 s. 2)
registration officer (登記主任) has the same meaning as it has in the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); (Added 31 of 1987 s. 2)
Registration of Persons Tribunal (人事登記審裁處) means the Registration of Persons Tribunal established by section 3C of the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); (Added 31 of 1987 s. 2)
removal order (遣送離境令) means an order under section 19(1);
right of abode in Hong Kong (香港居留權) means the right of abode in Hong Kong referred to in Part IA; (Added 31 of 1987 s. 2)
serviceman (軍人) means a person, not being locally engaged, who is a serving member of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army; (Amended 2 of 2012 s. 3)
ship (船、船隻) includes a barge, a hovercraft and every other description of vessel; (Added 61 of 1979 s. 2. Amended 78 of 1982 s. 2)

def.name: SpecifiedCountry
def.leadIn: specified place (指明地方) means a country, territory or place—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of which a person who is to be removed from Hong Kong is a national, citizen or resident;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in which that person has obtained a travel document;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in which that person embarked for Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to which an immigration officer or immigration assistant has reason to believe that that person will be admitted; (Added 31 of 2025 s. 22)

subsection.def: travel document (旅行證件) means a passport furnished with a photograph of the holder, or some other document establishing to the satisfaction of an immigration officer or immigration assistant the identity and nationality, domicile or place of permanent residence of the holder; (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10; 31 of 1984 s. 2)

def.name: TravelPass
def.leadIn: travel pass (旅遊通行證) means a document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: issued by the Director of Immigration to a person (other than a Hong Kong permanent resident) who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is not the holder of an identity card; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is the holder of an identity card (other than a permanent identity card within the meaning of the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177)) which belongs to a class of identity cards, if any, specified in writing by the Director of Immigration for the purposes of this definition; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which enables the holder of the document to enter Hong Kong as a visitor without a visa; (Added 6 of 1999 s. 2)

subsection.def: Tribunal (審裁處) means the Immigration Tribunal established by section 53F; (Added 62 of 1980 s. 2)

def.name: ValidTravelDocument
def.leadIn: valid travel document (有效旅行證件) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a passport furnished with a photograph, or any other document establishing to the satisfaction of an immigration officer or immigration assistant the identity and nationality of the holder of the document and the domicile or place of permanent residence of the holder of the document, which—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: indicates that it is still valid according to the laws of the country, territory or place by or on behalf of which it was issued;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: allows its holder to return to the country, territory or place by or on behalf of which it was issued; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: complies with section 61; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a document issued by or on behalf of a competent authority of any country, territory or place to its holder for the purpose of identification or travel, which— (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 22)

subparagraph.name: i
ii
iii
subparagraph.content: allows its holder to return to that country, territory or place; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: complies with section 61; (Replaced 13 of 2009 s. 3. Amended 31 of 2025 s. 22)

def.name: VietnameseRefugee
def.leadIn: Vietnamese refugee (越南難民) means a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: was previously resident in Vietnam; or (Amended 79 of 1982 s. 2)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: was born after 31 December 1982 and whose father or mother was previously resident in Vietnam; and (Added 79 of 1982 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is permitted to remain in Hong Kong as a refugee pending his resettlement elsewhere; (Added 35 of 1981 s. 2)

subsection.def: Vietnamese refugee card (越南難民證) means a card of identity issued by the Director to a Vietnamese refugee. (Replaced 35 of 1981 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: References in this Ordinance to landing in Hong Kong unlawfully are references to landing in or entering Hong Kong in contravention of this Ordinance, the repealed Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance or the repealed Immigrants Control Ordinance, and for the avoidance of doubt it is hereby declared that no person shall be held not to have landed unlawfully—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by reason only of any presumption, conclusive or rebuttable, that he cannot be guilty of an offence or is incapable of committing a crime; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the ground only that he is not guilty of an offence under subsection (1) of section 38 in respect of paragraph (a) of that subsection. (Amended 75 of 1981 s. 2)

subsection.content: References in this Ordinance to an offence under this Ordinance include references to an offence under section 90(1) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) where the arrestable offence which a person has committed is an offence under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, a person shall not be treated as ordinarily resident in Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: during any period in which he remains in Hong Kong— (Amended 122 of 1997 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: with or without the authority of the Director, after landing unlawfully; or (Amended 122 of 1997 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in contravention of any condition of stay; or (Amended 122 of 1997 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: as a refugee under section 13A; or (Added 42 of 1982 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: while detained in Hong Kong under section 13D; or (Added 23 of 1989 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: v
vi
subparagraph.content: while employed as a domestic helper who is from outside Hong Kong; or (Added 122 of 1997 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: as a member of a consular post within the meaning of the Consular Relations Ordinance (Cap. 557); or (Added 122 of 1997 s. 2. Amended 16 of 2000 s. 12)

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: as a member of the Hong Kong Garrison; or (Added 122 of 1997 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: ix
subparagraph.content: as a holder of a prescribed Central People’s Government travel document; or (Added 31 of 2002 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: during any period, whether before or after the commencement of this Ordinance, of imprisonment or detention pursuant to the sentence or order of any court.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (4)(a) does not apply to a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who acquired the right of abode in Hong Kong before 1 July 1997; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who remains in Hong Kong with the authority of the Director during the period from 1 July 1990 to 30 June 1997 inclusive after landing unlawfully and whom the Director may exclude from the application of subsection (4)(a). (Added 122 of 1997 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, a person does not cease to be ordinarily resident in Hong Kong if he is temporarily absent from Hong Kong. The circumstances of the person and the absence are relevant in determining whether a person has ceased to be ordinarily resident in Hong Kong. The circumstances may include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the reason, duration and frequency of any absence from Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether he has habitual residence in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: employment by a Hong Kong based company; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the whereabouts of the principal members of his family (spouse and minor children). (Added 122 of 1997 s. 2)

part.name: P1A
part.heading: Right of Abode in Hong Kong and Right to Land in Hong Kong

section.name: s2A
section.heading: Hong Kong permanent residents enjoy right of abode in Hong Kong

subsection.leadIn: A Hong Kong permanent resident enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong, that is to say he has, subject to section 2AA(2), the right— (Amended 124 of 1997 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to land in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not to have imposed upon him any condition of stay in Hong Kong, and any condition of stay that is imposed shall have no effect;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: not to have a deportation order made against him; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: not to have a removal order made against him.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding subsection (1)(c), no person against whom a deportation order was made prior to 1 July 1987 enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong unless the deportation order has expired or been revoked.

section.name: s2AAA
section.heading: Right to land in Hong Kong for former permanent residents

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: immediately before 1 July 1997 was a Hong Kong permanent resident under this Ordinance as then in force but did not become a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region upon the commencement of the Immigration (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 1997 (122 of 1997) shall, immediately upon such commencement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region but ceases to be such a permanent resident by virtue of the operation of this Ordinance shall, immediately upon such cessation,

subsection.continued: have the right—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: to land in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: not to have imposed upon him any condition of stay in Hong Kong, and any condition of stay that is imposed on him shall have no effect; and

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: not to have a removal order made against him.

subsection.content: If a deportation order is made against a person who has the right to land in Hong Kong under subsection (1), the right shall cease while the deportation order is in force.

For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that a holder of a permanent identity card defined in section 1A of the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177) whose permanent identity card could have been declared invalid under regulation 3D(1) of the Registration of Persons Regulations (Cap. 177 sub. leg. A) on the ground that he has never had the right of abode in Hong Kong shall not have the right to land in Hong Kong under subsection (1). (Amended E.R. 2 of 2018)

part.name: P1B
part.heading: Provisions relating to Permanent Residents under Paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1

section.name: s2AA
section.heading: Establishing status of permanent resident under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1

subsection.leadIn: A person’s status as a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1 can only be established by his holding of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a valid travel document issued to him and of a valid certificate of entitlement also issued to him and affixed to such travel document;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a valid HKSAR passport issued to him; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a valid permanent identity card issued to him.

subsection.content: A person’s right of abode in Hong Kong by virtue of his being a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1 can only be exercised upon the establishment of his status as such a permanent resident in accordance with subsection (1) and, accordingly, where his status as such a permanent resident is not so established, he shall, for the purposes of this Ordinance, be regarded as not enjoying the right of abode in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: immediately before 1 July 1997 did not enjoy the right of abode in Hong Kong under this Ordinance as then in force;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not the holder of a valid HKSAR passport or valid permanent identity card; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: claims to be a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1,

subsection.continued: may apply to the Director for a certificate of entitlement.

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall be made in such manner as the Director may specify by notice in the Gazette;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be made on behalf of an applicant by his parent, legal guardian or any other person acceptable to the Director and for the purposes of subsection (6)(b)(ii) and (iii) and section 2AD(1) such parent, legal guardian or other person shall be regarded as the applicant.

subsection.content: An application under subsection (1) which is not made in accordance with subsection (2)(a) and accompanied by the prescribed fee, if any, shall not be accepted.

For the removal of doubt, it is hereby declared that the making of an application under subsection (1) does not give the applicant the right of abode or right to land or remain in Hong Kong pending the decision of the Director on the application.

subsection.leadIn: Upon receipt of an application under subsection (1), the Director acting through an immigration officer authorized by him shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where he is satisfied upon such proof specified by the Director that the applicant is a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1, issue a certificate of entitlement to the applicant in the prescribed form and in such manner as the Director may determine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where he is not satisfied that the applicant is a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: refuse the application;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: notify the applicant in writing the reason of the refusal; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: inform the applicant the right of appeal to the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Director in processing an application made under subsection (1) is not otherwise satisfied that the applicant is born of a person of whom the applicant claims to be born, the Director—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may request the applicant and the person to undergo a genetic test conducted in such manner as the Director may specify by notice published in the Gazette to establish the claimed parentage; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall consider the result of the test and determine the application accordingly. (Added 17 of 2001 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: The Director may draw any inference from the failure of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an applicant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person of whom an applicant claims to be born,

subsection.continued: to undergo a genetic test referred to in subsection (7)(a) as he considers proper and determine the application accordingly. (Added 17 of 2001 s. 2)

subsection.content: Where the Director requests a person to undergo a genetic test under subsection (7)(a), he shall inform the person of the provision of subsection (8). (Added 17 of 2001 s. 2)
The Director may charge a fee for a genetic test referred to in subsection (7)(a). (Added 17 of 2001 s. 2)
The Director may, with the approval of the Financial Secretary, specify the amount of the fee charged under subsection (10) by notice published in the Gazette. (Added 17 of 2001 s. 2)
A notice under subsection (2)(a), (7)(a) or (11) is not subsidiary legislation. (Added 17 of 2001 s. 2)
If a certificate of entitlement issued to a person is lost or destroyed, he may apply to the Director for a certified duplicate of the certificate.

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall be made in such manner as the Director may specify by notice in the Gazette;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be made on behalf of an applicant by his parent, legal guardian or any other person acceptable to the Director and for the purposes of subsection (6)(b)(ii) and (iii) and section 2AD(2) such parent, legal guardian or other person shall be regarded as the applicant.

subsection.content: An application under subsection (1) which is not made in accordance with subsection (2)(a) and accompanied by the prescribed fee, if any, shall not be accepted.
A notice under subsection (2)(a) is not subsidiary legislation.

For the removal of doubt, it is hereby declared that the making of an application under subsection (1) does not give the applicant the right of abode or right to land or remain in Hong Kong pending the decision of the Director on the application.

subsection.leadIn: Upon receipt of an application under subsection (1), the Director acting through an immigration officer authorized by him shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where he is satisfied upon such proof specified by the Director that—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
subparagraph.content: a certificate of entitlement has been issued to the applicant; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the certificate of entitlement so issued is lost or destroyed,

paragraph.continued: issue a certified duplicate of that certificate to the applicant in such form and such manner as the Director may determine;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where he is not satisfied in the manner specified in paragraph (a)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: refuse the application;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: notify the applicant in writing the reason of the refusal; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: inform the applicant the right of appeal to the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: Where a certified duplicate issued to a person is lost or destroyed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person may apply to the Director for a further certified duplicate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: this section shall apply with all necessary modifications in relation to the application for and issue of the further certified duplicate.

subsection.content: Any applicant for a certificate of entitlement who is aggrieved by a decision of the Director not to issue the certificate may appeal against the decision to the Tribunal in a form specified by the Director within 90 days from the receipt of the notice given under section 2AB(6)(b)(ii).

Any applicant for a certified duplicate of a certificate of entitlement who is aggrieved by a decision of the Director not to issue the duplicate may appeal against the decision to the Tribunal in a form specified by the Director within 90 days from the receipt of the notice given under section 2AC(6)(b)(ii).
No appeal shall be lodged under subsection (1) or (2) at any time at which the appellant is in Hong Kong.
Notwithstanding subsection (1) or (2), the Tribunal may accept an appeal that is not lodged within the time limit prescribed in that subsection.

subsection.leadIn: On an appeal lodged under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the Tribunal determines that on the facts of the case as it finds them the appellant is a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1, it shall allow the appeal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the Tribunal determines that on the facts of the case as it finds them the appellant is not a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1, it shall dismiss the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: On an appeal lodged under subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where the Tribunal determines that on the facts of the case as it finds them—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the appellant is a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a certificate of entitlement has been issued to the appellant; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: that certificate is lost or destroyed,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where the Tribunal determines that on the facts of the case as it finds them—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the appellant is not a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a certificate of entitlement has not been issued to him; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the certificate of entitlement issued to him, if any, is not lost or destroyed,

subsection.content: The decision of the Tribunal under subsection (5) or (6) shall be final.

Where the Tribunal allows an appeal under subsection (5)(a) or (6)(a), the Director shall issue a certificate of entitlement or certified duplicate of a certificate of entitlement, as the case may require, to the appellant in such form and such manner as the Director may determine.

For the removal of doubt, it is hereby declared that the lodging of an appeal under subsection (1) or (2) does not give the appellant the right of abode or right to land or remain in Hong Kong pending the decision of the Tribunal on the appeal.

subsection.def: For the purposes of subsections (3), (5), (6), (8) and (9), appellant (上訴人) does not include a person making an application on behalf of another person under section 2AB(2)(b) or 2AC(2)(b).

section.name: s2AE
section.heading: No judicial review before Tribunal’s decision
section.leadIn: Where the Director refuses to issue—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a certificate of entitlement under section 2AB(6)(b)(i);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a certified duplicate of a certificate of entitlement under section 2AC(6)(b)(i),

section.continued: no application referred to in section 21K(3) of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4) for leave to apply for judicial review under section 21K(1) or (2) of that Ordinance may be made in respect of the refusal unless and until the Tribunal has made a decision under section 2AD(5) or (6), as the case may be, on an appeal lodged in respect of the refusal.

section.name: s2AF
section.heading: Invalidation of certificate of entitlement issued to unqualified person
section.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a certificate of entitlement has been issued to a person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person is not a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1,

section.continued: the certificate of entitlement shall be regarded for all purposes of this Ordinance (other than section 42) as never having been issued.

section.name: s2AG
section.heading: Prohibition of making application, etc. for reward

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: demands, seeks or receives or agrees to receive any payment, benefit, advantage or reward directly or indirectly in consideration of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: making an application for a certificate of entitlement under section 2AB or a certified duplicate under section 2AC on behalf of another person under section 2AB(2)(b) or 2AC(2)(b), as the case may be;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: giving advice in relation to individual application for a certificate of entitlement; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: offers to make or holds himself out as willing to make an application for a certificate of entitlement on behalf of another person in consideration of any payment, benefit, advantage or reward,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.content: The fact that the receipt of any payment, benefit, advantage or reward by a person is an offence under subsection (1) shall not prevent the recovery of any such payment, benefit, advantage or reward from any person.
Subsection (1) shall not apply to any solicitor or barrister acting in the course of his practice.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (2) and (6), the captain of a ship shall, on the arrival of the ship in Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: anchor or moor the ship at an approved immigration anchorage and keep the ship in such anchorage as long as may be necessary for the purposes of this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: hoist the prescribed immigration examination signal and keep the same hoisted until an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant permits him to lower it. (Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant may, on the arrival of a ship in Hong Kong, require the captain— (Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to anchor or moor the ship at such place as he may specify, being a place at which the captain considers that the ship may safely be moored or anchored;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to keep the ship in such place so long as may be necessary for the purposes of this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: but a requirement under this subsection shall cease to have effect if the captain is required by or under any other Ordinance to move the ship to another place.

subsection.leadIn: Except with the permission of the Director, no person other than a pilot or health officer in the course of his duty shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: board or leave a ship which has arrived in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be within 30 m of any such ship, otherwise than on a wharf or pier, (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 2)

subsection.continued: until the immigration examination signal is lowered.

subsection.content: Except with the permission of the Director, nothing shall be removed from or taken or placed on board a ship which has arrived in Hong Kong until the immigration examination signal is lowered.
The captain of an aircraft arriving in Hong Kong shall not land the aircraft except at an approved landing place.
The Director of Immigration may exempt from subsection (1) the captains of such ships, or of ships of such class or description as he thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, an immigration officer or immigration assistant may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), examine any person on his arrival or landing in or prior to his departure from Hong Kong, or if he has reasonable cause for believing that such person landed in Hong Kong unlawfully, at any time;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: examine a person at any time if he has reasonable cause for believing that such person is contravening or has contravened a condition of stay in respect of him, or remains in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant in contravention of section 7(2), (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 4)

subsection.continued: and a person who is so examined may be required by an immigration officer or immigration assistant to submit to further examination. (Amended 75 of 1981 s. 3)

subsection.content: A person who satisfies an immigration officer or immigration assistant that he is a serviceman shall not be examined further under subsection (1)(a) on his arrival in or prior to his departure from Hong Kong.

section.name: s4A
section.heading: Verification of identity of certain persons by automated means

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, the Director may provide automated means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to verify the identity of a person to whom this subsection applies;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to give permission to land in Hong Kong to any person referred to in paragraph (a) who by virtue of section 7(1) may not land in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to impose a limit of stay and such other conditions of stay, if permission is given to a person to land in Hong Kong under paragraph (b).

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) applies to a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is approved by the Director to use the automated means for the purposes set out in subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: voluntarily submits himself to have his identity verified by the automated means—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on his arrival or landing in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: prior to his departure from Hong Kong.

section.name: s4B
section.heading: Permission to land given by automated means

subsection.content: Any permission to land given by an automated means provided under section 4A shall be deemed to be permission to land given under section 11(1), and the other provisions of section 11 shall apply accordingly.

Any limit of stay and other conditions of stay imposed on a person by such an automated means shall be deemed to be a limit of stay and other conditions of stay imposed under section 11(2), and the other provisions of section 11 shall apply accordingly.

section.name: s4C
section.heading: Examination of persons after the verification of identity by automated means
section.content: Notwithstanding that a person has submitted himself voluntarily for verification of identity by an automated means provided under section 4A, any immigration officer or immigration assistant may examine the person under section 4(1)(a).

section.name: s5
section.heading: Powers of Director and requirements in relation to examinations under section 4 and verifications of identity under section 4A

subsection.leadIn: The Director may require—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner of a ship or aircraft or his agent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the captain of a ship or aircraft,

subsection.continued: to produce in such manner as the Director may specify for examination under section 4(1)(a) and verification of identity by an automated means provided under section 4A— (Amended 6 of 2005 s. 3)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the passengers arriving or departing in that ship or aircraft; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the members of the crew of that ship or aircraft.

subsection.leadIn: A requirement under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may relate to all or any of the passengers or all or any of the members of the crew or to all or any of both;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be made generally for all occasions or, without prejudice to any general requirement which may be in force, for any particular occasion.

subsection.content: An immigration officer or immigration assistant may require a person to proceed to such place as he may specify for the purpose of examination under section 4(1). (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10)

subsection.leadIn: Any person of or over the age of 16 years, other than a serviceman, being examined under section 4(1)(a) shall— (Amended 79 of 1982 s. 4; 31 of 1987 s. 5)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: produce a valid travel document, entry permit or re-entry permit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (9), furnish an arrival or departure card in the prescribed form, duly completed.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person being examined under section 4(1)(a) is of or over the age of 7 years and under the age of 16 years and— (Amended 79 of 1982 s. 4; 31 of 1987 s. 5)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: is accompanied by an adult, the adult shall—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: produce a valid travel document, entry permit or re-entry permit relating to such person; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subject to subsection (9), furnish in respect of such person an arrival or departure card in the prescribed form, duly completed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: having arrived or being about to depart in a ship or aircraft, is not accompanied by an adult, the owner of the ship or aircraft shall—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: produce a valid travel document, entry permit or re-entry permit relating to such person; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subject to subsection (9), furnish in respect of such person an arrival or departure card in the prescribed form, duly completed.

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer or immigration assistant may require any person, other than a serviceman, being examined under section 4(1) to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: declare whether or not he is in possession of any documents of any description specified by that officer or that assistant, being a description relevant for the purposes of the examination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: produce to the officer or the assistant any such documents which are in his possession. (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 3)

subsection.content: An immigration officer or immigration assistant may require a person being examined under section 4(1) to furnish to him such information as he may require for the purposes of this Ordinance. (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10)
An immigration officer or immigration assistant may give such directions as he considers necessary for preventing any person from evading examination under section 4(1). (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 3)
The Director of Immigration may exempt from subsection (4)(a), (4)(b), (5)(a)(ii) or (5)(b)(ii) any person or any class or description of persons. (Amended 21 of 1987 s. 2)

section.name: s6
section.heading: Returns to be furnished by captains of ships and aircraft, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), the captain of a ship shall, on the arrival of the ship in Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: furnish to an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 3 copies of a notice containing the prescribed particulars of the crew; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 2 copies of a notice containing the prescribed particulars of the passengers; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if so required by an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant, produce the ship’s papers.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), the captain of a ship shall, immediately before the departure of the ship from Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: furnish to an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 2 copies of a notice containing the prescribed particulars of the crew; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 2 copies of a notice containing the prescribed particulars of the passengers; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if so required by an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant, produce the ship’s papers.

subsection.content: An immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant may, on the arrival of an aircraft in Hong Kong and immediately prior to the departure of an aircraft therefrom, require the captain of the aircraft to furnish to him a notice containing the names and nationalities of the crew and a notice containing the prescribed particulars of the passengers.

A passenger on board a ship or aircraft arriving in or departing from Hong Kong shall furnish to the captain of the ship or aircraft any information required by him for the purpose of furnishing a notice under this section.
The Director of Immigration may exempt from this section the captains of such ships, or of ships of such class or description, as he thinks fit.

section.name: s6A
section.heading: Regulations relating to persons on board carriers

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary for Security may make regulations—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to provide for the supply to the Director of information or data relating to a carrier, its passengers or members of its crew, as may be specified in the regulations; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to empower the Director to direct that a passenger or a member of the crew of a carrier may or may not be carried on board the carrier.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), regulations made under this section may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: provide for the handling or disposal of information or data collected under the regulations; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide for the exercise or performance by the Director or any public officer of any powers or functions under the regulations.

subsection.leadIn: Regulations made under this section may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: be of general application or make different provisions for different cases or classes of cases;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: contain any incidental, consequential, evidential, transitional, saving or supplementary provisions that the Secretary for Security considers appropriate.

subsection.content: Regulations made under this section may provide that a contravention of a regulation (including a contravention in relation to any act, matter or omission that is done or happens wholly or partly outside Hong Kong) is an offence punishable by a fine not exceeding level 6.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: member of the crew (乘組人員), in relation to a carrier, means a person actually employed in the working or service of the carrier;
passenger (乘客) means a person carried, or to be carried, on board a carrier, other than a member of the crew.

section.name: s7
section.heading: General provision as to immigration control

subsection.leadIn: A person may not land in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant unless— (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: he enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong; or (Added 31 of 1987 s. 6)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: he has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA; or (Added 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he may land in Hong Kong without such permission by virtue of section 9(1) or 10(1). (Amended 79 of 1982 s. 5)

subsection.content: A person who was born in Hong Kong but who does not enjoy the right of abode in Hong Kong, or does not have the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA, may not remain in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant. (Added 79 of 1982 s. 5. Amended 31 of 1987 s. 6; 88 of 1997 s. 3; 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

section.name: s9
section.heading: Special provisions as to members of crew of aircraft

subsection.leadIn: Where a person who does not enjoy the right of abode in Hong Kong, or does not have the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA, arrives in Hong Kong as a member of the crew of an aircraft under an engagement requiring him to leave within 7 days on that or another aircraft as a member of its crew, then unless— (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 8; 88 of 1997 s. 5; 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a deportation order is in force in respect of him;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he has at any time been refused permission to land in Hong Kong and has not since then been given permission to land in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he is examined under section 4(1)(a) otherwise than for the purpose of establishing that he is such a member of the crew of an aircraft,

subsection.continued: he may land in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant and remain until the departure of the aircraft on which he is required by his engagement to leave.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, any such person who, having lawfully landed in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant by virtue of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: seeks permission to remain in Hong Kong beyond the time allowed by subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: remains in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant beyond the time so allowed or is reasonably suspected by an immigration officer or immigration assistant of intending to do so,

subsection.continued: shall thereupon be deemed to be a person seeking to land in Hong Kong; and an immigration officer or immigration assistant may examine him under section 4(1)(a) within 28 days thereafter or, if at that time he is detained in pursuance of the sentence or order of any court, within 28 days after his discharge from detention.

subsection.leadIn: Any such person who, having lawfully landed in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant by virtue of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: remains in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant beyond the time allowed by subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not submit himself to examination under section 4(1)(a) within the period during which in accordance with subsection (2) he may be examined by an immigration officer or immigration assistant under that section,

subsection.continued: shall on the expiry of that period be deemed for the purposes of this Ordinance to have landed in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant.

subsection.content: A serviceman may land in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, any such serviceman who ceases to be a serviceman shall thereupon, unless he enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong, or has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA, be deemed to be a person seeking to land in Hong Kong; and an immigration officer or immigration assistant may examine him under section 4(1)(a) within 28 days after— (Amended 88 of 1997 s. 6; 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he ceases to be a serviceman; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if at the time he ceases to be a serviceman he is detained in pursuance of the sentence or order of any court, his discharge from detention. (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 9)

subsection.content: Any such person who does not submit himself to examination under section 4(1)(a) within the period during which in accordance with subsection (2) he may be examined by an immigration officer or immigration assistant under that section shall on the expiry of that period be deemed for the purposes of this Ordinance to have landed in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Permission to land and conditions of stay

subsection.content: An immigration officer or immigration assistant may, on the examination under section 4(1)(a) of a person who by virtue of section 7(1) may not land in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant, give such person permission to land in Hong Kong but an immigration officer only may refuse him such permission. (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10; 79 of 1982 s. 6)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: An immigration officer or immigration assistant may, on the examination under section 4(1)(b) of a person who by virtue of section 7(2) may not remain in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant, give such person permission to remain in Hong Kong but an immigration officer only may refuse him such permission. (Added 79 of 1982 s. 6. Amended 31 of 1987 s. 10)

subsection.leadIn: Where permission is given to a person to land or remain in Hong Kong, an immigration officer or immigration assistant may impose— (Amended 79 of 1982 s. 6)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a limit of stay; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such other conditions of stay as an immigration officer or immigration assistant thinks fit, being conditions of stay authorized by the Director, either generally or in a particular case. (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10)

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (9), the permission given to a person to land or remain in Hong Kong shall be deemed to be subject to the prescribed conditions of stay in addition to any conditions of stay imposed under subsection (2). (Amended 79 of 1982 s. 6)

In the case of a person who is a member of a party in the charge of a responsible person, notice of any condition of stay shall be deemed to be given to such person if it is given in writing to the person in charge of the party.

The Director may at any time by notice in writing to any person other than a person who enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong, or has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA, impose any condition of stay (other than a limit of stay) in respect of such person. (Replaced 57 of 1972 s. 4. Amended 31 of 1987 s. 10; 88 of 1997 s. 7; 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant may at any time by notice in writing to any person other than a person who enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong, or has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA— (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 10; 65 of 1989 s. 3; 88 of 1997 s. 7; 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: cancel any condition of stay in force in respect of such person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: vary any condition of stay (other than a limit of stay) in force in respect of such person if the condition as varied could properly be imposed by an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant (other than the Director) under subsection (2)(b); (Amended 78 of 1982 s. 4; 65 of 1989 s. 3)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: vary any limit of stay in force in respect of such person by enlarging the period during which such person may remain in Hong Kong. (Added 57 of 1972 s. 4)

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may at any time vary any limit of stay in force in respect of any person by curtailing the period during which such person may remain in Hong Kong, and the Director shall in writing notify such person of any such variation. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive may by order applying to all persons or to any class or description of persons, other than persons who enjoy the right of abode in Hong Kong, or have the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA— (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 10; 88 of 1997 s. 7; 28 of 1998 s. 2(2); 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: cancel or vary any condition of stay in force in respect of such persons;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: impose any condition of stay (other than a limit of stay) in respect of such persons.

subsection.leadIn: Whenever a condition of stay is in force in respect of a person, the Director may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: require such person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if such person is a member of the crew of a ship or aircraft, require the captain of the ship or aircraft or the owners or agents of the ship or aircraft,

subsection.continued: to enter into a recognizance in the prescribed form in such amount and with such number of sureties as the Director may reasonably require.

subsection.content: The Director of Immigration may exempt any person or any class or description of persons from compliance with all or any of the prescribed conditions of stay.
Any permission given to a person to land or remain in Hong Kong shall, if in force on the day that person departs from Hong Kong, expire immediately after his departure. (Added 31 of 1984 s. 3)

section.name: s12
section.heading: Special provisions as to giving of permission to land to members of ship’s crew
section.text: An immigration officer or immigration assistant may permit a person who is a member of the crew of a ship and does not enjoy the right of abode in Hong Kong, or does not have the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA, to land in Hong Kong notwithstanding that he has not been examined under section 4(1)(a); and in any such case notice of any condition of stay imposed in respect of such person shall be deemed to have been given to that person if it is given to the captain of the ship or the owners or agents of the ship.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Authority for illegal immigrant to remain
section.content: The Director may at any time authorize a person who landed in Hong Kong unlawfully to remain in Hong Kong, subject to such conditions of stay as he thinks fit, whether or not he has been convicted of that offence, and section 11(5), (5A) and (6) shall apply to him as it applies to a person who has been given permission to land in Hong Kong under section 11(1).

subsection.leadIn: This Part does not apply to or in relation to a person in any case where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person arrives or lands in Hong Kong on or after the commencement of this section; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person arrives or lands in Hong Kong before the commencement of this section but is not detained under this Ordinance in connection with that arrival or landing until on or after that commencement.

subsection.leadIn: Where, after arriving or landing in Hong Kong, a person is subsequently removed from Hong Kong under this Ordinance or departs Hong Kong voluntarily, this Part shall cease to have any application to or in relation to the person in respect of that arrival or landing or of the period between that arrival or landing and the subsequent removal or departure from Hong Kong and, accordingly, as from the date of that removal or departure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all rights conferred on the person under this Part in respect of that arrival or landing or that period shall be extinguished; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no proceedings shall lie under this Part in respect of that arrival or landing or that period.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Except as provided in paragraph (b), subsection (2) applies whether the removal or departure referred to in that subsection is effected before, on or after the commencement of this section.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to a removal or departure from Hong Kong effected before the commencement of this section in any case where the person so removed or so departing—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: before that commencement, again arrived or landed in Hong Kong and had been detained under this Ordinance in connection with that arrival or landing; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: since the arrival or landing referred to in subparagraph (i), has not been removed from Hong Kong under this Ordinance and has not departed Hong Kong voluntarily.

editorialNote.content:
Editorial Note:
* This section was added by s. 2 of 8 of 1998. As to the operation of that
s. 2, please see s. 1(2) and (4) of 8 of 1998.

section.name: s13A
section.heading: Special conditions of stay regarding Vietnamese refugees

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant may permit any person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who was previously resident in Vietnam and who has been examined under section 4(1)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who was born after 31 December 1982 and whose father or mother was previously resident in Vietnam and who has been examined under section 4(1)(b), (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 13; 65 of 1989 s. 3)

subsection.continued: to remain in Hong Kong as a refugee pending his resettlement elsewhere. (Replaced 79 of 1982 s. 7. Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3; 48 of 1992 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant may at any time by notice in writing to a Vietnamese refugee impose any condition of stay or any further condition of stay which may include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a limit of stay;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a condition that such person shall reside in a refugee centre specified by an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant and shall comply with any rules made under section 13C; (Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a condition that such person shall not—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: take any employment, whether paid or unpaid;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: establish or join in any business; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: become a student at a school, university or other educational institution.

subsection.leadIn: Every Vietnamese refugee who has been permitted to remain in Hong Kong whether before or after the commencement of the Immigration (Amendment) Ordinance 1981 (35 of 1981) shall be subject to a condition of stay that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if he is made an offer of resettlement elsewhere he shall not without reasonable excuse fail or refuse—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to accept the offer; nor

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to comply with any requirement necessary for the completion of the resettlement procedure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if he is required by an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant to surrender the Vietnamese refugee card held by him, he shall not without reasonable excuse fail or refuse to surrender forthwith the Vietnamese refugee card. (Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant may at any time by notice in writing to a Vietnamese refugee— (Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: cancel any condition of stay in force in respect of such person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: vary any condition of stay (other than a limit of stay) in force in respect of such person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: vary any limit of stay in force in respect of such person by curtailing or enlarging the period during which such person may remain in Hong Kong.

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: Any Vietnamese refugee who remains in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant beyond the period allowed by any limit of stay specified in any condition of stay in force in respect of him shall be deemed for the purposes of this Ordinance to have landed in Hong Kong unlawfully upon the expiration of such period. (Added 42 of 1982 s. 3. Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3)
A notice under subsection (2) or (4) shall be given to a Vietnamese refugee in such manner as may be prescribed.
The Secretary for Security may by order designate any place as a refugee centre for the residence of Vietnamese refugees. (Amended 42 of 1982 s. 6; 48 of 1992 s. 5)

The Secretary for Security may make rules providing for the treatment, and control of conduct, of Vietnamese refugees in refugee centres and for the management and security of, and the maintenance of order, discipline, cleanliness and hygiene in, refugee centres, and different rules may be made in respect of different centres. (Replaced 42 of 1982 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (2), rules made under that subsection may provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contravention of any provision thereof to be punished by the imposition of a penalty not exceeding $500 and by separate confinement for a period not exceeding 28 days; (Amended 42 of 1982 s. 6)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the confinement of persons punished by separate confinement;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the imposition, by a specified public officer, of such punishment for such contravention;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: appeals against the imposition of punishment and the practice and procedure relating to such appeals;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the payment and the disposal of monetary penalties in any manner whatsoever.

section.name: s13D
section.heading: Detention pending decision as to permission to remain in Hong Kong, or pending removal from Hong Kong

subsection.leadIn: As from 2 July 1982 any resident or former resident of Vietnam who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: arrives in Hong Kong not holding a travel document which bears an unexpired visa issued by or on behalf of the Director; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has not been granted an exemption under section 61(2),

subsection.continued: may, whether or not he has requested permission to remain in Hong Kong, be detained under the authority of the Director in such detention centre as an immigration officer may specify pending a decision to grant or refuse him permission to remain in Hong Kong or, after a decision to refuse him such permission, pending his removal from Hong Kong, and any child of such a person, whether or not he was born in Hong Kong and whether or not he has requested permission to remain in Hong Kong, may also be so detained, unless that child holds a travel document with such a visa or has been granted an exemption under section 61(2). (Replaced 52 of 1991 s. 2)

subsection.name: 1AA
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (1AB) and (1AC), where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person is being detained pending his removal from Hong Kong; and

def.name: PendingRemoval
def.leadIn: a request has been made to the Government of Vietnam by—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; or (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees acting through his representative in Hong Kong,

def.continued: for approval to remove the person to Vietnam,

subsection.name: 1AB
subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, nothing in subsection (1AA) shall be interpreted as giving authority to the Director under subsection (1) to detain a person for a purpose other than pending his removal from Hong Kong. (Added 33 of 1996 s. 2)

subsection.name: 1AC
subsection.content: For the further avoidance of doubt, nothing in subsection (1AA) shall prevent a court, in applying subsection (1A), from determining that a person has been detained for an unreasonable period. (Added 33 of 1996 s. 2)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: The detention of a person under this section shall not be unlawful by reason of the period of the detention if that period is reasonable having regard to all the circumstances affecting that person’s detention, including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a person being detained pending a decision under section 13A(1) to grant or refuse him permission to remain in Hong Kong as a refugee—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the number of persons being detained pending decisions under section 13A(1) whether to grant or refuse them such permission; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the manpower and financial resources allocated to carry out the work involved in making all such decisions;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a person being detained pending his removal from Hong Kong—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the extent to which it is possible to make arrangements to effect his removal; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whether or not the person has declined arrangements made or proposed for his removal. (Added 52 of 1991 s. 2)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: The detention of a person under this section pending a decision under section 13A(1) to grant or refuse him permission to remain in Hong Kong as a refugee shall not be unlawful by reason that other persons (who may or may not have arrived in Hong Kong after the detainee) who were detained pending decisions under section 13A(1) to grant or refuse them such permission were granted or refused such permission within periods shorter than the period of the person’s detention. (Added 52 of 1991 s. 2)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.content: Where a judge has ordered the release of a person detained under this section in proceedings for habeas corpus, the Director may, with the consent of the person so released, require him to enter into a recognizance under section 36(1) as though he were being detained under section 32. (Added 33 of 1996 s. 2)

Every person detained under this section shall be permitted all reasonable facilities to enable him to obtain any authorization required for entry to a country or territory, or a place outside Hong Kong, or, whether or not he has obtained such authorization, to leave Hong Kong. (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 23)

Where a person is detained under subsection (1) after a decision under section 13A(1) to refuse him permission to remain in Hong Kong as a refugee, such person as the Director may authorize for the purpose shall serve on the detained person a notice in such form as the Director may specify notifying him of his right to apply for a review under section 13F(1). (Added 23 of 1989 s. 3. Amended 52 of 1991 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Notice under subsection (3) may be served—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: personally; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by displaying it in some prominent place within the area where the person concerned is detained in such a manner that it may be conveniently read by him. (Added 23 of 1989 s. 3)

subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that any person detained under subsection (1) in any place may, under the authority of the Director of Immigration, be transferred from that place and detained in any other place or places specified by the Director of Immigration. (Added 52 of 1991 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding subsection (5), a person detained under subsection (1) in a detention centre shall not be transferred from that detention centre to another detention centre on the ground that his transfer is necessary in the interests of order or good management in the first mentioned detention centre unless the Director of Immigration has—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: certified that his transfer is so necessary; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: caused written notice to be served on the person informing him of the ground on which he is to be so transferred. (Added 52 of 1991 s. 2)

subsection.content: A certificate purporting to be signed by the Director of Immigration stating that the transfer, from one detention centre to another, of a person detained under subsection (1) is necessary in the interests of order or good management in the detention centre in which the person is detained shall be admitted in evidence in any proceedings on its production without further proof and, until the contrary is proved, shall be presumed to have been signed by the Director of Immigration. (Added 52 of 1991 s. 2)

If, before 31 May 1991, any person detained under subsection (1) in any place was, under the authority of any public officer other than the Director of Immigration, transferred from that place and detained in any other place specified by that public officer, the Director of Immigration shall be deemed to have delegated that public officer to exercise on his behalf the powers conferred on him in that respect. (Added 52 of 1991 s. 2)

editorialNote.content: * As to operation of section 13D(5), see 52 of 1991 section 1(2) and (3).

section.name: s13DA
section.heading: Appeals against transfer on ground of order or good management

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any person detained under section 13D(1) is transferred from one detention centre to another; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director of Immigration has certified that the transfer is necessary in the interests of order or good management in the detention centre from which he was transferred,

subsection.continued: the person may appeal against the transfer to the officer appointed by the Secretary for Security under section 13H(2) to have control and management of the detention centre from which he is transferred (the relevant officer).

subsection.content: A person who wishes to appeal under subsection (1) shall serve written notice of appeal, stating his grounds of appeal and the facts upon which he relies, upon the superintendent of the detention centre to which he is transferred, within 48 hours after his transfer to that detention centre; but such notice shall not preclude the person from raising other facts prior to the determination of his appeal by the relevant officer and relying upon those facts.
An appeal under subsection (1) shall be considered by the relevant officer, who may confirm, vary or cancel the transfer.
A decision of the relevant officer under subsection (3) shall be final.

subsection.def: In this section, superintendent of the detention centre (羈留中心的監督) means the person appointed to be in charge of the detention centre by the officer appointed by the Secretary for Security under section 13H(2) to have control and management of the detention centre.

section.name: s13E
section.heading: Removal from Hong Kong of Vietnamese refugees and persons detained under section 13D

subsection.content: The Director may at any time order any Vietnamese refugee or person detained in Hong Kong under section 13D to be removed from Hong Kong.

An immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant may remove from Hong Kong in accordance with section 24 any person ordered to be removed from Hong Kong under subsection (1). (Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3)

section.name: s13F
section.heading: Review by a Refugee Status Review Board

subsection.content: Any person on whom a notice is served under section 13D(3) may, within 28 days of such service, apply to the Board to have the decision that he may not remain in Hong Kong as a refugee reviewed.
An application for a review under this section may be made on behalf of a child by his parent or any person having care of the child.

subsection.leadIn: In preparing his case for review under this section an applicant shall be permitted all reasonable facilities to enable him to obtain the assistance of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his legal representative, if he has one; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, a prescribed person,

subsection.continued: and such representative or person shall be afforded all reasonable facilities to enable him to render such assistance.

subsection.content: Neither the applicant nor his representative shall be entitled to be present when his case is reviewed by a Board.

Upon the hearing of the review a Board shall make such decision as to the status of the appellant and as to his continued detention under section 13D(1) as it may think fit, being a decision which the Director might lawfully have made under this Ordinance, and the Director shall give effect to such decision.

For the removal of doubt, it is hereby declared that the making of an application under this section does not give the person by whom or on whose behalf it is made the right to land or remain in Hong Kong pending the decision of a Board on the application.
A Board when considering any review under this section shall act in an administrative or executive capacity.
A Board shall not be required to assign any reason for its decision and a decision of a Board shall not be subject to review or appeal in any court.

Any resident or former resident of Vietnam or any child of such resident or former resident who prior to the commencement of the Immigration (Amendment) Ordinance 1989 (23 of 1989) objected under section 53 to a refusal to grant him permission to remain in Hong Kong as a refugee or to his detention or removal under section 13D shall, if his objection is pending at the commencement of that Ordinance, be deemed to have applied to a Refugee Status Review Board for a review of that decision under subsection (1). (23 of 1989 s. 6(1) incorporated)

The chairman of the Refugee Status Review Boards may authorize or direct that the rules of practice and procedure on review prescribed under section 59 as read with section 13G(5) shall be modified in such manner as he may direct for the purpose of hearing an application to which subsection (9) applies. (23 of 1989 s. 6(2) incorporated)

Where a decision has been made to refuse any resident or former resident of Vietnam permission to remain in Hong Kong as a refugee not more than 14 days prior to the commencement of the Immigration (Amendment) Ordinance 1989 (23 of 1989), the period of 28 days referred to in subsection (1) shall, in his case, be reckoned as commencing on the commencement of that Ordinance, as if a notice under section 13D, notifying him of that decision had been served at the time of such commencement. (23 of 1989 s. 6(3) incorporated)

There shall be Refugee Status Review Boards and there shall be a Chairman, and such number of Deputy Chairmen and members of those Boards as may be appointed by the Chief Executive. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

Persons appointed by the Chief Executive under subsection (1) may be public officers and shall be appointed for such periods and on such terms as the Chief Executive may determine. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

The remuneration, if any, of the Chairman, a Deputy Chairman and members of the Boards shall be determined by the Financial Secretary and paid out of moneys appropriated by the Legislative Council for the purpose.
A Board shall be constituted from persons appointed under subsection (1) in such manner as may be prescribed.

subsection.leadIn: The practice and procedure on a review under section 13F, and of a Board, shall be such as shall be prescribed and, without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing and of section 59, regulations under that section may prescribe—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the manner in which an application under section 13F is to be made, including the furnishing of grounds therefor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the constitution of a Board and the manner in which decisions are to be taken;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the exclusion of persons from the proceedings of a Board;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: prescribing a person for the purposes of section 13F(3)(b) and deeming that person to be the representative of the applicant, in such circumstances and to such extent as may be specified;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the matters which a Board is entitled to consider; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the manner in which decisions are to be notified.

subsection.content: The Secretary for Security may by order designate any place as a detention centre for the detention of persons authorized to be detained there under section 13D.

subsection.leadIn: A detention centre shall be under the control and management of an officer appointed by the Secretary for Security and the officer appointed shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner of Correctional Service;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Commissioner of Police; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Chief Staff Officer, Civil Aid Service. (Amended 58 of 1997 s. 34)

subsection.content: The officer who has been appointed by the Secretary for Security to have control and management of a detention centre may issue such general orders and instructions not inconsistent with this Ordinance or any rules made under this section as are necessary or expedient for the administration of the detention centre under his control.

Every officer and other person employed in a detention centre shall in the exercise of any powers, functions or duties under this Ordinance or rules made under this section comply with any general orders and instructions issued under subsection (3).

The Secretary for Security may make rules providing for the treatment, and control of conduct, of such detainees in detention centres and for the management and security of, and the maintenance of order, discipline, cleanliness and hygiene in, detention centres, and for the punishment of offenders.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (5), rules made under that subsection may provide for—

paragraph.name: a
