paragraph.content: contravention of any provision thereof by a detained person to be punished by the imposition of a penalty not exceeding $500 and by separate confinement for a period not exceeding 28 days;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the separate confinement of persons and the circumstances under which a person may be so confined;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the imposition, by a specified public officer, of such punishment for such contravention;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: searching of detainees and visitors and detention for the purpose of search;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: appeals against the imposition of punishment and the practice and procedure relating to such appeals;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the confiscation of unauthorized articles and the disposal thereof;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the payment and the disposal of monetary penalties in any manner whatsoever;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the powers, duties, conduct and discipline of officers of the person having control and management of the detention centres and other persons employed in the detention centres;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the duties and powers of visiting justices;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the appointment of detention centre visitors and the duties of such detention centre visitors;

paragraph.name: k
l
paragraph.content: permitting detainees to be absent from detention centres whilst continuing to be in legal custody, (Added 52 of 1991 s. 4)

subsection.continued: and different rules may be made in respect of different detention centres.

subsection.content: Rules made under subsection (5) may provide that a contravention of any provision thereof shall be an offence and may provide penalties therefor not exceeding a fine at level 2 and imprisonment for 6 months.

part.name: P4
part.heading: Supply of Particulars by Aliens and by Persons Staying in Hotels or Other Lodging Places

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), an alien within Hong Kong who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: attains the age of 16 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: having previously been exempted from this subsection or section 5(4)(b), (5)(a)(ii) or (5)(b)(ii) (otherwise than by reason of his age), ceases to be so exempted,

subsection.continued: shall within 1 month thereafter furnish to the Director in the prescribed form the particulars required thereby.

subsection.content: The Director of Immigration may exempt from subsection (1) any person or any class or description of persons.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Powers to require alien to produce photographs

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), an immigration officer or immigration assistant may require an alien within Hong Kong who is over the age of 15 years to furnish the prescribed photographs of himself. (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10)

subsection.leadIn: A requirement shall not be made under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: unless the alien has been in Hong Kong for at least 14 days; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the alien has furnished such photographs to the Director within the preceding 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), an alien who is over the age of 15 years shall within 7 days notify the Director of any change in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any of the particulars furnished in an arrival card;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any of the particulars furnished in the prescribed form pursuant to section 14(1);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any particulars notified pursuant to this subsection; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the address at which he resides.

subsection.content: The Director of Immigration may exempt from subsection (1) any person or any class or description of persons.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Record of visitors to hotels, etc.

subsection.content: A person over the age of 15 years who intends to stay at any premises to which this section applies shall on arriving at the premises inform the keeper of the premises of his full name and nationality.

subsection.leadIn: Any such person who is an alien shall also—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on arriving at the premises, inform the keeper of the premises of the date of his arrival in Hong Kong, the name of the ship or airline (if any) by which he arrived and his occupation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on or before his departure from the premises, inform the keeper of the premises of the place to which he is going and, if he is departing from Hong Kong, of the ship or airline (if any) by which he will depart.

subsection.leadIn: The keeper of any premises to which this section applies shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: require all persons who stay at the premises to comply with their obligations under this section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: keep for at least 12 months a record in writing of the information given to him by any such person pursuant to this section.

subsection.content: An immigration officer, immigration assistant or police officer may inspect at any time the record kept by the keeper of any premises pursuant to subsection (3). (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10)
Any information required by this section to be given by or to any person may be given by or to any other person acting on his behalf.
This section applies to any premises, whether furnished or unfurnished, where lodging or sleeping accommodation is provided for reward.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: keeper (管理人) includes any person who receives another person to stay in premises, whether on his own behalf or on behalf of any other person;
stay (暫住) means lodge or sleep, for one night or more, in accommodation provided for reward.

part.name: P4A
part.heading: Requirement to Carry Proof of Identity

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may from time to time, by order published in the Gazette, declare that this Part, or any provision of this Part specified in the order— (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall come into operation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall be discontinued in its operation.

subsection.content: Where an order is made under subsection (1)(a), this Part or, as the case may be, any provision specified in the order, shall continue in operation until an order is made in relation to it under subsection (1)(b); and where an order is made under subsection (1)(b) in relation to this Part or any provision of it, the operation of this Part or, as the case may be, of that provision shall be discontinued until such time as a further order is made under subsection (1)(a) in relation to it.

Section 23 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) shall have the same effect in relation to the discontinuance of the operation of any provision by virtue of an order under subsection (1)(b) as it would have if such provision had been repealed.

editorialNote.content:
Editorial Note:
* Part IVA came into operation on 30 October 1980 (L.N. 302 of 1980).

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), in this Part—

def.name: ProofOfIdentity
def.leadIn: proof of identity (身分證明文件) in relation to any person means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his valid identity card; (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 14)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a document issued by the Commissioner of Registration acknowledging that that person has applied—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to be registered under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: for a new identity card under regulation 13 or 14 of the Registration of Persons Regulations (Cap. 177 sub. leg. A);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a valid travel document held by him;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: documentary proof of identity officially issued to him for the purpose of his service in the Chinese People’s Liberation Army; or (Amended 2 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a Vietnamese refugee card issued to him. (Amended 35 of 1981 s. 4)

subsection.content: The Legislative Council may by resolution amend subsection (1) by deleting from or adding to the list of documents which may be used as proof of identity under this Part. (Added 35 of 1981 s. 4)

section.name: s17C
section.heading: Carrying and production of proof of identity

subsection.leadIn: Every person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has attained the age of 15 years; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is the holder of an identity card or is required to apply to be registered under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is the holder of a Vietnamese refugee card,

subsection.continued: shall have with him at all times proof of his identity.

subsection.leadIn: A person who is required by subsection (1) to have with him proof of his identity shall on demand produce it for inspection by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any police officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any immigration officer or immigration assistant; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any person or member of a class of persons authorized for the purpose by the Chief Executive by order published in the Gazette, (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.continued: who is in uniform or who produces, if required to do so, documentary identification officially issued to him as proof of his appointment as a police officer, immigration officer, immigration assistant or, as the case may be, person authorized under paragraph (c).

content.leadIn: Any person who fails to produce proof of his identity for inspection as required by subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 2: (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)
content.proviso: Provided that it shall be a defence in proceedings for an offence under this subsection for the person charged to prove that he had reasonable excuse for failing to produce proof of identity.

def.name: ProofOfIdentity
def.leadIn: In respect of any failure to produce proof of identity for inspection as required by subsection (2), it shall be reasonable excuse for the purposes of subsection (3) if at the date of the alleged offence the defendant had no proof of identity with him because all proof of identity of which he was the holder, including any document specified in paragraph (b)(ii) of the definition of proof of identity in section 17B(1), had been lost or destroyed and— (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 156)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he had reported the loss or destruction to a police officer at a police station or, in the case of an identity card, to a registration officer; or (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 15)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he had had no opportunity so to report the loss or destruction.

subsection.content: Where the Chief Executive authorizes any person or class of persons for the purposes of subsection (2)(c) he may limit the authority of such persons to such area, place or occasion or in such other manner as is specified in the order by which the authority is given. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

Nothing in this section shall affect the operation of any order made under regulation 11(1) of the Registration of Persons Regulations (Cap. 177 sub. leg. A) (relating to the compulsory carrying of identity cards).

A person referred to in section 17C(2)(a), (b) or (c) may arrest without warrant any person who fails to produce for inspection on demand proof of his identity, and in the case of such an arrest by a person referred to in section 17C(2)(a) or (c), the person arrested shall if not released be delivered as soon as reasonably practicable into the custody of the officer in charge of a police station.
An arrest carried out under subsection (1) shall not be unlawful by reason only of the fact that the arrested person is a person not required by section 17C(1) to have proof of his identity with him.

Where a person is arrested under subsection (1) otherwise than by an immigration officer or immigration assistant and it appears to the officer in charge of a police station that he may have landed in Hong Kong unlawfully, or have intended or attempted so to do, or is contravening or has contravened a condition of stay in respect of him, he shall be taken as soon as is reasonably practicable to an immigration officer or immigration assistant for examination under section 17E. (Amended 75 of 1981 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Where a person who is arrested under subsection (1) otherwise than by an immigration officer or immigration assistant and is not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: taken before an immigration officer or immigration assistant under subsection (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceeded against for an offence under section 17C(3),

subsection.continued: he shall be released forthwith unless he may be held in lawful custody for some other reason.

section.name: s17E
section.heading: Examination of persons not carrying proof of identity
section.content: Without prejudice to any other provision of this Ordinance, an immigration officer or immigration assistant may examine any person who is found not to have with him proof of his identity in order to determine whether that person has landed in Hong Kong unlawfully or intended or attempted so to do or is contravening or has contravened a condition of stay in respect of him.

part.name: P4B
part.heading: Prohibition of Employment of Illegal Immigrants and Others

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may from time to time, by order published in the Gazette, declare that this Part, or any provision of this Part specified in the order— (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall come into operation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall be discontinued in its operation.

subsection.content: Where an order is made under subsection (1)(a), this Part or, as the case may be, any provision specified in the order, shall continue in operation until an order is made in relation to it under subsection (1)(b); and where an order is made under subsection (1)(b) in relation to this Part or any provision of it, the operation of this Part or, as the case may be, of that provision shall be discontinued until such time as a further order is made under subsection (1)(a) in relation to it.

Section 23 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1) shall have the same effect in relation to the discontinuance of the operation of any provision by virtue of an order under subsection (1)(b) as it would have if such provision had been repealed.

editorialNote.content:
Editorial Note:
* Sections 17G, 17H and 17J came into operation on 28 October 1980.
Sections 17I, 17K, 17L, 17M and 17N came into operation on 3 November 1980. (L.N. 303 of 1980)

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: appointed day (指定日期) means the day last declared under section 17F(1)(a) for section 17I to come into operation;
approved document (認可文件) means a document approved by the Chief Executive under subsection (2)(c)(v); (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

certificate of exemption (豁免證明書) means a certificate issued by the Commissioner of Registration to a person who by virtue of regulation 25(e) of the Registration of Persons Regulations (Cap. 177 sub. leg. A) (relating to the aged, the blind and the infirm) is not required to be registered under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177);

contract of employment (僱傭合約) means any agreement, whether in writing or oral, express or implied, whereby one person agrees to employ another and that other agrees to serve his employer as an employee and includes a contract of apprenticeship;
employee (僱員) means any person who has entered into a contract of employment to be employed by any other person as an employee or apprentice;

employer (僱主) means any person who has entered into a contract of employment to employ any other person as an employee or apprentice, and the duly authorized agent, manager or factor of such first mentioned person;

def.name: IdentityCard
def.leadIn: identity card (身分證) includes a document issued by the Commissioner of Registration acknowledging that the holder has applied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be registered under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a new identity card under regulation 13 or 14 of the Registration of Persons Regulations (Cap. 177 sub. leg. A);

subsection.def: official passport (公務護照) means a passport issued by a government of any place outside China, to an employee of that government for the purpose of carrying out official duties; (Amended 23 of 1998 s. 2)
record of employees (僱員紀錄) means a record required to be kept under section 17K.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to any provision of this Ordinance relating to conditions of stay which may be imposed on any person, a person is lawfully employable for the purposes of this Part only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is the holder of an identity card and he has not breached any condition of stay (if any) imposed on him under this Ordinance; (Amended 59 of 1996 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he is the holder of an official passport; (Amended 23 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: the person is a claimant who has a substantiated claim under Part VIIC and is the holder of a permission given by the Director under section 37ZX; or (Added 23 of 2012 s. 3)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: he is not required to be registered under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177) and— (Amended 13 of 2009 s. 4)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is the holder of a valid travel document and, having landed in Hong Kong lawfully, is not prohibited from taking employment, whether paid or unpaid, under any condition of stay, and in respect of whom no removal order or deportation order is in force; (Replaced 13 of 2009 s. 4)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: is the holder of a Vietnamese refugee card which does not prohibit him from taking employment; (Amended 35 of 1981 s. 6)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: is the holder of a certificate of exemption; or

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: is the holder of any other document of a type approved by the Chief Executive by order published in the Gazette. (Amended 13 of 2009 s. 4; 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: An employee may be required by his employer to produce for inspection within the time limited by subsection (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the employee’s identity card;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the employee’s official passport; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: where the employee is not the holder of an identity card and is not required to be registered under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a valid travel document;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a Vietnamese refugee card or a document issued by the Director acknowledging that the employee is the holder of a Vietnamese refugee card which is reported lost or destroyed;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: a certificate of exemption; or

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: any other approved document,

subsection.leadIn: A requirement may be made under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: at any time prior to the appointed day in the case of an employee who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is in Hong Kong; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is not absent from work; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: upon the first return to work of an employee who between the day on which an order under section 17F(1)(a) was last made and the appointed day—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: was outside Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: was absent from work.

subsection.leadIn: Where an employee fails—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the appointed day to comply with a requirement made in accordance with subsection (2)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within 72 hours of his return to work, to comply with a requirement made in accordance with subsection (2)(b),

subsection.continued: his employer shall be entitled to terminate the employment of such employee without notice or payment in lieu and no liability, either at common law or under any Ordinance, shall attach to the employer by reason of such termination or for any loss thereby suffered by the employee:
subsection.proviso: Provided that if at any time after the time limited by this subsection the employee produces to his employer for inspection any document which should have been produced within the time so limited, the employee’s employment shall, if it has not already been terminated, cease upon such production to be liable to be terminated under this subsection.

section.name: s17I
section.heading: Offence to be employer of a person who is not lawfully employable

subsection.leadIn: Any person who is the employer of an employee who is not lawfully employable commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment— (Amended 75 of 1990 s. 2; L.N. 25 of 1996; 7 of 2021 s. 4)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the employee is not a prohibited employee—to a fine of $350,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the employee is a prohibited employee—to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 10 years. (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 4)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: It is a defence in proceedings for an offence under this section for the person charged to prove that all practicable steps were taken to determine whether the employee in respect of whom the offence is alleged to have been committed was lawfully employable and that it was reasonable to conclude that the employee was lawfully employable. (Added 75 of 1990 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: It shall be a defence in proceedings for an offence under this section for the person charged to prove that the employee in respect of whom the offence is alleged to have been committed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: had been absent from work continuously from the date when section 17H last came into operation until 72 hours before the date of the alleged offence; (Amended 23 of 2012 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is the holder of a Vietnamese refugee card, that at the time the contract of employment was entered into with the employee the Vietnamese refugee card held by the employee did not prohibit the employee from taking employment and that the person charged had no knowledge that the Vietnamese refugee card held by the employee was, after the contract of employment was entered into, replaced by a new Vietnamese refugee card prohibiting the employee from taking employment; or (Replaced 35 of 1981 s. 7. Amended 23 of 2012 s. 4)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: was the holder of a permission given by the Director under section 37ZX that permitted the employee to take employment at the time the contract of employment was entered into and the person charged had no knowledge that the permission had expired after that time. (Added 23 of 2012 s. 4)

subsection.content: It shall not be a defence in proceedings for an offence under this section that the employee entered the employment of the employer before the appointed day. (Added L.N. 346 of 1982)

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is charged with an offence under this section a certificate purporting to be signed by the Director and certifying that the employee in respect of whom the offence is alleged to have been committed was, at the date of the alleged offence, not lawfully employable, shall be admitted in evidence on its production without further proof and, until evidence to the contrary is adduced, it shall be presumed— (Amended 48 of 1992 s. 6)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the certificate was signed by the Director; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the employee in respect of whom the offence is alleged to have been committed was, at the date of the alleged offence, not lawfully employable. (Added 30 of 1989 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a body corporate commits an offence under this section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is proved that the offence was committed with the consent or connivance of, or was attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate,

subsection.continued: the director, manager, secretary or other similar officer also commits the offence. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a partner in a partnership commits an offence under this section; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is proved that the offence was committed with the consent or connivance of, or was attributable to any neglect on the part of, any other partner in the partnership or any other person concerned in the management of the partnership,

subsection.continued: the other partner or the other person concerned in the management of the partnership also commits the offence. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: prohibited employee (受禁僱員) means a person who is prohibited from taking any employment or establishing or joining in any business under section 38AA. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 4)

section.name: s17J
section.heading: Employers to inspect documents of new employee

subsection.leadIn: No person shall in Hong Kong enter into a contract of employment to employ any other person unless he first inspects—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the identity card held by such other person and where the identity card held by such other person is not a permanent identity card as defined in the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177), a valid travel document held by him; (Replaced 59 of 1996 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the official passport held by such other person; (Amended 23 of 2012 s. 5)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: if such other person is a claimant who has a substantiated claim under Part VIIC, the Director’s permission given under section 37ZX; or (Added 23 of 2012 s. 5)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: where such other person is not the holder of an identity card and is not required to be registered under the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a valid travel document;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a Vietnamese refugee card;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: a certificate of exemption; or

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: any other approved document,

subsection.content: Any person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 1 year. (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)

section.name: s17JA
section.heading: Employers to inspect regularly Vietnamese refugee cards of employees and termination of employment

subsection.content: Every employer shall, where he has in his employment any employee who is the holder of a Vietnamese refugee card, require such employee to produce for inspection the Vietnamese refugee card held by the employee on every occasion wages are paid by the employer to the employee to ensure that the employee is lawfully employable.

subsection.leadIn: Where an employee to whom subsection (1) applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is the holder of a Vietnamese refugee card which prohibits him from taking employment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails or refuses to produce for inspection, within 72 hours of his being required to do so under subsection (1), the Vietnamese refugee card held by him,

subsection.continued: his employer shall be entitled to terminate the employment of such employee without notice or payment in lieu and no liability, either at common law or under any Ordinance, shall attach to the employer by reason of such termination or for any loss thereby suffered by the employee:
subsection.proviso: Provided that if at any time after the time limited by paragraph (b) the employee produces to his employer for inspection the Vietnamese refugee card which should have been produced within the time so limited, the employee’s employment shall, if it has not already been terminated and if the employee is not prohibited from taking employment, cease upon such production to be liable to be terminated under this subsection.

section.name: s17K
section.heading: Records to be kept by employers

subsection.leadIn: Every employer shall keep at the place of employment of each of his employees a record of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the full name of the employee as shown in his identity card or other document by virtue of which he is lawfully employable; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the type of document held by the employee by virtue of which he is lawfully employable, and the number of that document.

subsection.content: Every employer shall, where he employs more than 10 employees at any one place of employment, keep at that place the records of those employees in the form of a list of the names and particulars of those employees required under subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: Every employer shall keep the record of each employee and every list required to be kept under subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: up to date;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in a form which is capable of being produced on demand to a person authorized to inspect it; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in a form which is legible and capable of being readily understood by any person authorized to inspect it.

subsection.def: In this section place of employment (工作地方) in relation to an employee who has no single place of employment, means his principal place of employment.

subsection.leadIn: A person employed as a senior labour inspector or labour inspector in the Labour Department shall, if in uniform or upon production of his authority if required, have authority to enter any premises or place where he has reasonable cause to believe that persons are in employment, other than such premises or place as are principally used for dwelling purposes, and— (Amended 39 of 1997 s. 50)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to require an employer there to produce on demand for inspection any record or list which an employer is required to keep under section 17K; (Replaced 30 of 1989 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to require an employee there to produce on demand for inspection any document which the employee is required by section 17C to have with him; (Replaced 30 of 1989 s. 4)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to seize and remove any thing which may appear to him to be evidence of an offence under section 17M. (Added 30 of 1989 s. 4)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Any employer from whom any records or lists which an employer is required to keep under section 17K or other documents have been seized and removed under subsection (1)(c) shall, pending any proceedings for an offence under section 17M, be entitled to make copies of and take extracts from such records, lists or other documents and it shall be the duty of the Director at all reasonable times, and subject to such reasonable conditions as to security or otherwise as he may impose, to give the employer access to them for that purpose. (Added 30 of 1989 s. 4)

Any immigration officer or immigration assistant and any police officer may, if in uniform or upon production of his authority if required, without prejudice to any other provision of this Ordinance or to any other law call for, inspect and copy any record of employees.

A person employed as a senior labour inspector or labour inspector in the Labour Department may, by notice in writing served on an employer, require the employer to produce to him for inspection any record or list which an employer is required to keep under section 17K before the expiry of such time being not less than 72 hours as shall be specified in the notice. (Amended 39 of 1997 s. 50)

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (1) may be served by serving a copy—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: personally;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by registered post addressed to the last known place of business or residence of the person to be served; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: on any person who appears to the person serving the notice to be an employee of the person to be served.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: contravenes section 17K(1), (2) or (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fails to produce for inspection a record or list of employees when lawfully required to do so, (Amended 30 of 1989 s. 6)

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5.

subsection.content: Any person who fails or refuses to produce for inspection a document the production of which is required under section 17L(1)(b) commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 2.

content.leadIn: Any person who obstructs any public officer in the execution of his duty under this Part commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months:
content.proviso: Provided that it shall be a defence in proceedings for an offence under this subsection for the person charged to prove that he did not act unreasonably having regard to all the circumstances of the offence charged.

section.name: s17N
section.heading: Presumption
section.leadIn: Any person who is found at a place where employees are in the employment of an employer shall, unless evidence is adduced that he is lawfully employable, be presumed in the absence of evidence to the contrary— (Amended 48 of 1992 s. 7)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to have entered into a contract of employment to be employed by that employer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to be an employee of that employer.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Removal of persons refused permission to land and of members of ship’s crew who contravene certain conditions of stay

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant may remove from Hong Kong in accordance with section 24— (Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who, pursuant to any examination whatsoever under section 4(1)(a), is under section 11(1) refused permission to land in Hong Kong; and (Amended 75 of 1981 s. 6)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a person who, having arrived in Hong Kong on board a ship in which he was a member of the crew and been given permission to land in Hong Kong subject to a condition of stay requiring him to leave Hong Kong—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in a specified ship; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: within a specified period in accordance with arrangements for his repatriation,

paragraph.continued: contravenes or is reasonably suspected by an immigration officer of intending to contravene that condition.

subsection.content: A person who is refused permission to land in Hong Kong may not be removed from Hong Kong under subsection (1)(a) after the expiry of 2 months beginning with the date on which he landed. (Amended 75 of 1981 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: A removal order may be made against a person requiring him to leave Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by the Chief Executive if it appears to him that that person is an undesirable immigrant who has not been ordinarily resident in Hong Kong for 3 years or more; or (Amended 82 of 1993 s. 3; 88 of 1997 s. 9; 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: by the Director if it appears to him that that person— (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 16)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: might have been removed from Hong Kong under section 18(1) if the time limited by section 18(2) had not passed; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: has (whether before or after commencement of the Immigration (Amendment) (No. 4) Ordinance 1981 (75 of 1981)) landed in Hong Kong unlawfully or is contravening or has contravened a condition of stay in respect of him; or (Replaced 75 of 1981 s. 7. Amended 79 of 1982 s. 8)

subparagraph.name: iia
subparagraph.content: not being a person who enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong, or has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA, has contravened section 42; or (Added 31 of 1984 s. 7. Amended 31 of 1987 s. 16; 88 of 1997 s. 9; 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: being a person who by virtue of section 7(2) may not remain in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant, has remained in Hong Kong without such permission. (Added 79 of 1982 s. 8)

subsection.content: A removal order made against a person shall invalidate any permission or authority to land or remain in Hong Kong given to that person before the order is made or while it is in force.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Director makes a removal order he shall cause written notice to be served as soon as is practicable on the person against whom it is made informing him—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of the ground on which the order is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that if he wishes to appeal he must do so by giving to an immigration officer or immigration assistant written notice of his grounds of appeal and the facts upon which he relies within 24 hours of receiving the notice of the order.

subsection.def: In this section Director (處長) means the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration or any assistant director of immigration. (Amended 8 of 1998 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive may make a deportation order against an immigrant if— (Amended 78 of 1982 s. 6; 31 of 1987 s. 17; 88 of 1997 s. 10; 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the immigrant has been found guilty in Hong Kong of an offence punishable with imprisonment for not less than 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Chief Executive deems it to be conducive to the public good. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.content: A deportation order shall require the person against whom it is made to leave Hong Kong and shall prohibit him from being in Hong Kong at any time thereafter or during such period as may be specified in the order.
A deportation order made against a person shall invalidate any permission or authority to land or remain in Hong Kong given to that person before the order is made or while it is in force.

For the purposes of this section, the question whether an offence is one for which a person is punishable with imprisonment shall be determined without regard to any Ordinance restricting the imprisonment of young offenders. (Amended 88 of 1997 s. 10)

part.name: P6
part.heading: Supplementary Provisions as to Removal and Deportation

section.name: s24
section.heading: Removal by immigration officer under section 18

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is to be removed from Hong Kong under section 18 or 13E in a ship or aircraft, an immigration officer may give directions— (Amended 42 of 1982 s. 8)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to the captain of the ship or aircraft in which that person arrived in Hong Kong requiring him to remove that person from Hong Kong in that ship or aircraft;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the owners or agents of the ship or aircraft in which that person arrived in Hong Kong requiring them to remove that person from Hong Kong in any ship or aircraft specified or indicated in the directions, being a ship or aircraft of which they are the owners or agents;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to the said owners or agents requiring them to make arrangements for the removal of that person from Hong Kong in any ship or aircraft specified or indicated in the directions to a specified place; (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 24)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to the owners or agents of any ship or aircraft requiring them to make arrangements for the removal of that person from Hong Kong in any ship or aircraft specified or indicated in the directions to a specified place, notwithstanding that such person did not arrive in Hong Kong in a ship or aircraft of which they are the owners or agents or in any ship or aircraft. (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 24)

subsection.content: A person in respect of whom directions are given under subsection (1) may be placed under the authority of an immigration officer or immigration assistant on board any ship or aircraft in which he is to be removed in accordance with the directions. (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: Where the ship in which a person arrived in Hong Kong is a ship not exceeding 500 gross tons—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the captain of that ship may be required under subsection (1)(a) to remove that person from Hong Kong forthwith in that ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an immigration officer or a chief immigration assistant may take such steps as he thinks necessary to procure the immediate departure of that ship from Hong Kong. (Amended 65 of 1989 s. 3)

subsection.content: A person may be removed from Hong Kong under section 18 or 13E by land to a specified place; and for that purpose may be taken in the custody of an immigration officer, immigration assistant or police officer to the place at which he is to be removed. (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 6; 42 of 1982 s. 8; 31 of 2025 s. 24)

Subject to section 25(5) and (5A), the expenses of or incidental to the removal from Hong Kong of a person who is removed in accordance with directions under subsection (1)(d) shall be met from moneys provided by the Legislative Council, but save as aforesaid the expenses of or incidental to the removal from Hong Kong of a person who is removed in accordance with directions under subsection (1) shall be met by the owners of the ship or aircraft. (Amended 31 of 1984 s. 9)

section.name: s25
section.heading: Removal pursuant to removal order or deportation order

subsection.content: A person in respect of whom a removal order or a deportation order is in force may be removed from Hong Kong in accordance with this section.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may give directions—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: to the owners or agents of any ship or aircraft requiring them to make arrangements for the removal of such person from Hong Kong in a ship or aircraft specified or indicated in the directions to any such place. (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 25)

subsection.content: A person in respect of whom directions are given under subsection (2) may be placed under the authority of an immigration officer, immigration assistant or police officer on board any ship or aircraft in which he is to be removed in accordance with the directions. (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 7)

A person in respect of whom a removal order or a deportation order is in force may be removed by land to a specified place, and for that purpose may be taken in the custody of an immigration officer, immigration assistant or police officer to the place at which he is to be removed. (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 7; 31 of 2025 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Secretary for Administration may apply in or towards payment of the expenses of or incidental to— (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the voyage from Hong Kong of a person in respect of whom a removal order or a deportation order is in force; and (Amended 31 of 1984 s. 10)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the maintenance until departure of such a person and his dependants, if any,

subsection.continued: any money belonging to that person; and except so far as they are paid as aforesaid the expenses of or incidental to the removal from Hong Kong of a person in respect of whom a removal order or a deportation order is in force shall be met from moneys provided by the Legislative Council.

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.content: Any expenses under subsection (5) or section 24(5) or any part thereof met from moneys provided by the Legislative Council may be recovered from the person concerned as a civil debt due to the Government. (Added 31 of 1984 s. 10)

Without prejudice to subsection (5) or (5A), the Chief Secretary for Administration may require any person to whom subsection (5)(a) applies to use for the purposes of the voyage from Hong Kong any aeroplane or ship ticket or voucher issued in respect of that person. (Added 52 of 1976 s. 2. Amended 31 of 1984 s. 10; L.N. 362 of 1997)

section.name: s26
section.heading: Power to detain for inquiry
section.leadIn: Without prejudice to any other provision of this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where any member of the Immigration Service of or above the rank of chief immigration officer or any police officer of or above the rank of superintendent is satisfied— (Amended 31 of 1984 s. 11)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that inquiry for the purposes of this Ordinance, other than the provisions relating to deportation, is necessary in the case of any person; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that such person may abscond if he is not detained,

paragraph.continued: such person may be detained for not more than 48 hours; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where any member of the Immigration Service of or above the rank of principal immigration officer or any police officer of or above the rank of assistant commissioner of police is so satisfied, such person may be detained for not more than a further 5 days.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Detention pending examination and decision as to landing
section.leadIn: A person who may be examined under section 4(1)(a) or is required to submit to further examination following an examination under section 4(1)(a) may be detained under the authority of an immigration officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for not more than 24 hours pending the examination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for not more than a further 24 hours pending a decision to give or refuse him permission to land.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Detention for inquiry as to deportation

subsection.leadIn: If it appears to the Secretary for Security—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for inquiry as to whether a person ought to be deported under section 20; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that such person should be detained for the purposes of or during such inquiry,

subsection.continued: he may issue a warrant in the prescribed form authorizing the detention of such person for a period of 14 days.

subsection.leadIn: If it appears to the Secretary for Security that it is desirable that a person detained under a detention warrant should be further detained—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purposes referred to in subsection (1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purpose of inquiries into activities of that person which are prejudicial to the security of Hong Kong, being inquiries which in the opinion of the Secretary for Security should be conducted before the proceedings for the deportation of such person are completed; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: while proceedings for his deportation are completed,

subsection.continued: the Secretary for Security may issue not more than 2 further warrants in the prescribed form authorizing the detention of such person for a further period of 7 days in each case. (Amended 48 of 1992 s. 9)

subsection.content: Any police officer may arrest a person in respect of whom a detention warrant is in force.
The Secretary for Security may at any time direct that a person detained under a detention warrant be released.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who is in Hong Kong in contravention of a deportation order in force in respect of him is to be removed from Hong Kong under section 25; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: it appears to the Chief Executive— (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the continued presence of such person in Hong Kong is necessary for the time being in connection with inquiries being carried on into activities of that person which are prejudicial to the security of Hong Kong; and (Amended 48 of 1992 s. 10)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that such person may abscond if he is not detained,

subsection.continued: the Chief Executive may issue a warrant in the prescribed form authorizing the detention of such person for a period of 14 days.

subsection.content: If it appears to the Chief Executive that a person detained under a warrant issued under subsection (1) or this subsection should be further detained for such purpose, he may issue not more than 2 further warrants in the prescribed form authorizing the detention of such person for a further period of 7 days in each case. (Amended 48 of 1992 s. 10)
The Chief Executive may at any time direct that a person detained under a warrant issued under subsection (1) or (2) be no longer detained thereunder.

subsection.leadIn: A person who is to be removed from Hong Kong under section 18 or 13E— (Amended 42 of 1982 s. 8)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be detained pending his removal under that section, and may be so detained for not more than 48 hours under the authority of an immigration officer and thereafter under the authority of the Director; and (Amended 8 of 1998 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may, if he is on board a ship or aircraft, be removed therefrom under the authority of an immigration officer for detention under this subsection.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Where consideration is being given to applying for or making a removal order in respect of a person, that person may be detained as provided for in subsection (2) or (2A), whichever is appropriate in the particular case. (Added 62 of 1980 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: A person may be detained under the authority of the Secretary for Security—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for not more than 14 days pending the making of an application to the Chief Executive for a removal order under section 19(1)(a) in respect of that person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for not more than a further 14 days pending the decision of the Chief Executive as to whether or not a removal order should be made under section 19(1)(a) in respect of that person. (Replaced 62 of 1980 s. 6. Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: A person may be detained pending the decision of the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration or any assistant director of immigration as to whether or not a removal order should be made under section 19(1)(b) in respect of that person— (Amended 8 of 1998 s. 4)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for not more than 7 days under the authority of the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration or any assistant director of immigration; (Amended 8 of 1998 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for not more than a further 21 days under the authority of the Secretary for Security; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where inquiries for the purpose of such decision have not been completed, for a further period of 21 days under the authority of the Secretary for Security, in addition to the periods provided under paragraphs (a) and (b). (Added 62 of 1980 s. 6)

subsection.content: A person in respect of whom a removal order under section 19(1)(a) or a deportation order is in force may be detained under the authority of the Secretary for Security pending his removal from Hong Kong under section 25. (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 4; 62 of 1980 s. 6)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: A person in respect of whom a removal order under section 19(1)(b) is in force may be detained under the authority of the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration or any assistant director of immigration pending his removal from Hong Kong under section 25. (Added 62 of 1980 s. 6. Amended 8 of 1998 s. 4)

subsection.name: 3B
subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (3C) and (3D), where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person is being detained pending his removal from Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.text: a request has been made to the relevant authorities of a place outside Hong Kong by the Government for approval to remove the person to that place,

subsection.def: for the purposes of detention under subsection (1), (3) or (3A), pending removal (等候遣離) includes awaiting a response to the request from those authorities. (Added 8 of 1998 s. 3)

subsection.name: 3C
subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, nothing in subsection (3B) shall be interpreted as giving authority under subsection (1), (3) or (3A) to detain a person for a purpose other than pending his removal from Hong Kong. (Added 8 of 1998 s. 3)

subsection.name: 3D
subsection.content: For the further avoidance of doubt, nothing in subsection (3B) shall prevent a court, in applying subsection (4A), from determining that a person has been detained for an unreasonable period. (Added 8 of 1998 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding subsections (1), (1A), (2), (2A), (3) and (3A), a person who is to be removed from Hong Kong under section 18 or 13E or in respect of whom a removal order or a deportation order is in force may be detained— (Amended 62 of 1980 s. 6; 42 of 1982 s. 8)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: under the authority of the Secretary for Security for not more than 28 days; and (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by order of a court on the application of the Secretary for Justice for further periods, not exceeding 21 days upon any one application, (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.continued: for the purpose of giving evidence at the trial of any offence or of facilitating inquiries into any offence or suspected offence. (Added 42 of 1979 s. 3)

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.leadIn: The detention of a person under this section shall not be unlawful by reason of the period of the detention if that period is reasonable having regard to all the circumstances that justify its length, including, in the case of a person being detained pending removal from Hong Kong— (Added 8 of 1998 s. 3. Amended 7 of 2021 s. 5)

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: the extent to which it is possible to make arrangements to effect the person’s removal;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: whether the person’s removal is directly or indirectly prevented or delayed by any action or lack of action of the person, including the person not obtaining, or not providing assistance to obtain, any authorization from the relevant authorities of a place outside Hong Kong that is required for the person’s entry to that place;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the time required for the issue of the authorization referred to in paragraph (d);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: whether the person poses, or is likely to pose, a threat or security risk to the community; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: factors that directly or indirectly prevent or delay the person’s removal that are not within the control of the Director. (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 5)

subsection.def: In subsection (4), court (法院) includes the District Court and a magistrate. (Added 42 of 1979 s. 3)

section.name: s33
section.heading: Detention of persons on board ships or aircraft

subsection.leadIn: The captain of a ship or aircraft shall, if so required by an immigration officer, immigration assistant or police officer, take such steps as may be necessary for preventing— (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 8)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person who arrived in the ship or aircraft and has been refused permission to land in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person placed on board the ship or aircraft under section 24(2) or 25(3),

subsection.continued: from landing from the ship or aircraft before it leaves Hong Kong.

subsection.content: For the purpose of preventing any such person from landing from the ship or aircraft, the captain of the ship or aircraft may detain that person in custody on board the ship or aircraft.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Detention of person arrested under section 54(3)
section.leadIn: A person who is arrested under section 54(3) may be detained—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by any police officer for the purpose of inquiries for not more than 48 hours; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: under the authority of the Secretary for Security for not more than a further 28 days pending the decision of the Chief Executive as to whether or not the suspension of the deportation order made against him should be rescinded. (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 5; 82 of 1993 s. 6; 21 of 2024 s. 78)

section.name: s35
section.heading: General provisions as to detained persons

subsection.content: Save as otherwise provided in this Ordinance, persons required or authorized to be detained by or under this Ordinance may be detained in such places as the Secretary for Security may by order direct; and the Chief Executive may by order provide for the treatment of persons so detained. (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 6; 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this Ordinance, the Secretary for Security may direct that— (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 6; 42 of 1982 s. 9)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person required or authorized to be detained by or under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: persons of such class or description as he may specify, being persons required or authorized to be detained by or under this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: may be detained in such other place as he may specify, and—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: a person in respect of whom such a direction has been given; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: a person of any class or description in respect of which such a direction has been given,

subsection.continued: may be detained in such place.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to any other Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any person detained by virtue of this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person who, being detained in pursuance of the sentence or order of a court, would otherwise be liable to be detained by virtue of this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: may be taken in the custody of an immigration officer, immigration assistant, officer of the Correctional Services Department or police officer to and from any place where his attendance is required for any purpose of this Ordinance. (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 9; 42 of 1982 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: Any person required or authorized to be detained by or under this Ordinance may be arrested without warrant by an immigration officer, immigration assistant, officer of the Correctional Services Department or police officer; and any person who is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: detained by virtue of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being removed from one place in which he is detained by virtue of this Ordinance to another place in which he may be so detained; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: being taken to any place in the custody of an immigration officer, immigration assistant, officer of the Correctional Services Department or police officer in accordance with this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: shall be deemed to be in lawful custody. (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 9; 42 of 1982 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer and any police officer may require a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: who is detained under section 27, 32, 34 or 37ZK; or (Amended 48 of 1992 s. 11; 88 of 1997 s. 15; 23 of 2012 s. 6)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: who, being liable to be detained under any of those sections, is not for the time being so detained,

subsection.continued: to enter into a recognizance in the prescribed form in such amount, with such number of sureties and subject to such conditions as the immigration officer or police officer may reasonably require or impose; and where a person who is so detained enters into such a recognizance he may be released. (Amended 23 of 2012 s. 6)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the conditions of a recognizance imposed under that subsection may include a condition that the person must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: report in person at the time and intervals, and at the office or police station, specified by the immigration officer or police officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notify an immigration officer or police officer in writing of any change in the person’s residential or correspondence address as soon as practicable after the change;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: (if the person is a claimant as defined by section 37U(1)) attend interviews as required by section 37ZAB. (Added 23 of 2012 s. 6. Amended 7 of 2021 s. 6)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: An immigration officer or police officer may vary any condition of a recognizance imposed under subsection (1). (Added 23 of 2012 s. 6)

A person may be detained under section 27, 32, 34 or 37ZK notwithstanding that he has entered into a recognizance pursuant to a requirement under subsection (1); and where such person is so detained otherwise than in consequence of or following a breach of the recognizance, the recognizance shall thereupon cease to have effect. (Amended 48 of 1992 s. 11; 88 of 1997 s. 15; 23 of 2012 s. 6)

If it appears to a magistrate on the application of the Director that any person may become liable to be detained under section 32(2), the magistrate may order that person to enter into a recognizance in the prescribed form in such amount and with such number of sureties as he thinks fit. (Added 52 of 1976 s. 3)
The magistrate may order any person who wilfully fails to comply with an order under subsection (3) to be imprisoned for 6 months. (Added 52 of 1976 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: A recognizance entered into pursuant to subsection (3) shall cease to have effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the person who has entered into the recognizance has been detained under section 32(2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the person who has entered into the recognizance has a removal order or deportation order made against him;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where it is decided that a removal order will not be made in respect of him;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: upon the expiration of 6 months from the date on which the recognizance was entered into or upon the expiration of the period for which the recognizance has been extended under subsection (6),

subsection.continued: whichever is the earlier. (Added 52 of 1976 s. 3)

subsection.content: A magistrate may, on application by the Director prior to the expiration of a recognizance entered into pursuant to subsection (3), extend the recognizance for such period not exceeding 6 months as the magistrate thinks fit. (Added 52 of 1976 s. 3)

section.name: s37
section.heading: Recovery of cost of maintaining person detained under section 32(1)
section.content: If a person who is detained under section 32(1) pending his removal from Hong Kong under section 18 arrived in Hong Kong in a ship or aircraft, the Director of Immigration may require the owner of the ship or aircraft or his agent to pay to the Government the expense incurred by it in maintaining that person during his detention.

section.name: s37A
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: passage (旅程) in relation to an unauthorized entrant includes the travel and transport of the unauthorized entrant by ship, aircraft, vehicle or any other means whatsoever; and

unauthorized entrant (未獲授權進境者) means a person belonging to a class or description of persons who, by an order made under section 37B, are declared to be unauthorized entrants, other than a person who under subsection (2) of that section is excepted from the declaration in such order.

subsection.content: The Chief Executive in Council may by order declare any class or description of persons, other than persons who enjoy the right of abode in Hong Kong, or have the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA, to be unauthorized entrants. (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 20; 88 of 1997 s. 16; 28 of 1998 s. 2(2); 21 of 2024 s. 78)
A declaration under subsection (1) may be made subject to such exceptions as are specified in the order.

section.name: s37C
section.heading: Offence by crew etc., of ship carrying unauthorized entrants

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), if a ship enters Hong Kong with an unauthorized entrant on board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: each member of the crew;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the owner of the ship and his agent; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any person who participated in making arrangements to enable the voyage on which the unauthorized entrant boarded the ship or was brought to Hong Kong to take place,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $5,000,000 and to imprisonment for 14 years; and (Amended 82 of 1993 s. 7)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $350,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years. (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: The captain or owner of a ship shall not be convicted of an offence under subsection (1) if he proves that at the time of the entry of the ship into Hong Kong he did not know, had no reason to suspect and could not with reasonable diligence have discovered that there was on board the ship any unauthorized entrant.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: A person who is a member of the crew of a ship other than the captain shall not be convicted of an offence under subsection (1) if he proves that prior to the commencement of the voyage on which the unauthorized entrant was brought to Hong Kong, he did not know and had no reason to suspect that any unauthorized entrant would be carried on the ship.

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: A person accused of an offence under subsection (1)(c) shall not be convicted of such offence if he proves that on the date or dates on which he participated in making any such arrangements as are referred to in that subsection he did not know and had no reason to suspect that any unauthorized entrant would be carried on the ship.

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: A person who is the agent of the owner of a ship shall not be convicted of an offence under subsection (1) if he proves—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that prior to the commencement of the voyage on which any unauthorized entrant was brought to Hong Kong, he did not know and had no reason to suspect that any unauthorized entrant would be carried on the ship; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that he informed the Director at the earliest practicable opportunity of the presence on board the ship of unauthorized entrants.

section.name: s37D
section.heading: Arranging passage to Hong Kong of unauthorized entrants

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), any person who, on his own behalf or on behalf of any other person, whether or not such other person is in Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: arranges or assists the passage to, or within, Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: offers to arrange or assist the passage to, or within, Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: does or offers to do an act preparatory to or for the purpose of arranging or assisting the passage to, or within, Hong Kong,

subsection.continued: of a person who is, or of a conveyance which carries, an unauthorized entrant, commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $5,000,000 and to imprisonment for 14 years; (Amended 82 of 1993 s. 8)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine of $350,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years. (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)

subsection.leadIn: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (1) if he proves that he did not know, had no reason to suspect and could not with reasonable diligence have discovered—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the person whose carriage on a conveyance or whose passage is the subject of the charge, was an unauthorized entrant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the conveyance in relation to which he is charged was carrying, or would carry, any unauthorized entrant,

subsection.continued: as the case may be.

subsection.def: In this section conveyance (運輸工具) means a ship, aircraft, vehicle or any other means whatsoever of travel or transport.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who assists an unauthorized entrant to remain in Hong Kong commits an offence and shall be liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 10 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine of $250,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years. (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)

subsection.content: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (1) if he proves that he did not know, had no reason to suspect and could not with reasonable diligence have discovered that the person he assisted was an unauthorized entrant.
Where a ship is used in the commission of an offence under section 37C or 37D, the ship shall be liable to forfeiture whether or not any person is convicted of any such offence.

content.leadIn: With the approval in writing of the Secretary for Justice the Director may seize and detain any ship which appears to him to be liable to forfeiture under subsection (1) and within 21 days of any such seizure the Director shall serve notice of the seizure on the owner of the ship: (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)
content.proviso: Provided that where there is more than one owner of a ship it shall be sufficient for the purposes of this subsection to give notice to one of the owners.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (2) shall be deemed to have been duly served on the owner if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is delivered to him, or to the person whom the Director believes to be the owner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is sent by registered post addressed to such person at the place of residence or business of such person, if any, known to the Director; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where in the opinion of the Director it is not practicable to serve the notice in accordance with paragraph (a) or (b) it is published in accordance with subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: Within 21 days of the seizure of any ship which appears to the Director to be liable to forfeiture under subsection (1), notice of the seizure of the ship shall be published—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the Gazette; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in 1 newspaper published in Hong Kong in the English language and 1 newspaper so published in the Chinese language.

subsection.content: Any person who has a claim to a ship which has been seized (in this section and in section 37F referred to as the claimant) may, within 30 days of the publication in the Gazette of notice of the seizure, give notice in writing to the Director that he claims that the ship is not liable to forfeiture.

A notice under subsection (5) shall state an address within Hong Kong at which the claimant may be served in any proceedings arising out of the claim and in any such proceedings a document addressed to the claimant and sent by post to, or delivered at, that address shall for the purposes of this Part be deemed to be duly served on the claimant.

The Director may at any time prior to the expiration of the period of time specified in subsection (5), terminate the seizure of the ship by serving notice to that effect on the owner in accordance with subsection (3), or in a similar manner on the person in possession of the ship at the time it was seized; and within 14 days of so terminating the seizure of the ship, the Director shall release the ship to the owner or to such person and publish notice of the termination of the seizure in the manner provided in subsection (4).

If, on the expiry of the period of time specified in subsection (5) for the giving of a notice of a claim, no such notice has been given in writing to the Director, the ship shall thereupon be deemed to be duly forfeited to the Government. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: A person has a claim for the purposes of this section and section 37F if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is the owner of the ship, or of an interest in the ship, or is the agent of the owner; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he was in possession of the ship at the time it was seized.

subsection.content: Where a notice of claim is given under section 37E(5) and the Director does not terminate the seizure under section 37E(7), the Director shall apply for the forfeiture of the ship.

An application under subsection (1) may be made to a magistrate, the District Court or to the Court of First Instance, as the Secretary for Justice thinks fit. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

When an application under subsection (1) is made to a magistrate, the magistrate shall issue a summons to the claimant requiring him to appear before a magistrate on the hearing of the application and shall cause a copy of the summons to be served on the Director.

When an application under subsection (1) is made to the District Court or the Court of First Instance, it shall be made and proceeded with, and may be withdrawn, in accordance with rules of court, and may be begun by motion. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: If on the hearing of an application made under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: neither the claimant nor any other person appears before the court to make a claim and the court is satisfied that notice of the date of the hearing was duly served on the claimant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: neither the claimant nor any person satisfies the court that he has a claim,

subsection.continued: and the court is satisfied that the ship is liable to forfeiture, the court shall order that the ship be forfeited to the Government. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: If, on the hearing of an application made under subsection (1) and not withdrawn, the court is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ship is liable to forfeiture; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person has a claim in respect thereof,

subsection.continued: it shall order that the ship be forfeited to the Government unless that person satisfies the court that it is just and equitable in all the circumstances— (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: that the ship should not be forfeited; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: that the ship should not be forfeited but that instead a sum under subsection (7) should be paid to the Government. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: Where the court does not order that the ship be forfeited, it shall order that the ship be released to the owner or his agent either without payment to the Director or upon payment to the Director of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such sum, if any, as appears to the court to be sufficient to reimburse the Government for expenditure reasonably incurred or to be incurred by the Government in seizing and detaining the ship and in supplying goods and services to it and to any person on board the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such sum, if any, as appears to the court to be just and equitable in lieu of forfeiture of the ship, having regard to all the circumstances including the value of the ship, the degree of blameworthiness of the owner or other claimant and any other relevant factors.

subsection.content: If any sum ordered to be paid under subsection (7) is not paid to the Director within 1 month of the date of the order, then the ship shall thereupon be deemed to be duly forfeited to the Government without prejudice to any order for the payment of any sum under subsection (7)(a), which may be recovered as a civil debt due to the Government. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)
Where the court orders that the ship be forfeited, it may in addition order the owner or other claimant to pay to the Director the sum specified in subsection (7)(a).

On the hearing of an application made under subsection (1), a certified true copy of the record of any proceedings, including the decision of the court, in respect of an offence under section 37C or 37D shall be admissible in evidence, and for the avoidance of doubt it is declared that such application is a civil proceeding.

Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, an application to a magistrate under subsection (1) may with the leave of the magistrate be withdrawn at any time prior to the making of an order under subsection (6) or (7), and shall be deemed for the purpose of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) to be a complaint to which section 8 of that Ordinance applies.

section.name: s37G
section.heading: Forfeiture of property
section.leadIn: An application may at any time be made by the Secretary for Justice to a magistrate in the prescribed form, or in accordance with rules of court to the District Court or the Court of First Instance by motion, for forfeiture under this section and if upon hearing such application or, where no such application is made, in the course of a prosecution for an offence under section 37C or 37D, it appears to the court that any property other than a ship— (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been, is being or is intended to be used in the commission or to procure or facilitate the commission of an offence under section 37C or 37D; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is the proceeds or represents the proceeds, directly or indirectly (as being the result of any disposal or realization of the whole or part of the proceeds) of any such offence,

section.continued: the court shall, whether or not any person is convicted of any such offence, order the forfeiture of such property unless it is satisfied that it would not be just to do so or that there is other good reason why it should not do so.

section.name: s37H
section.heading: Compensation for seizure of ship or property
