subsection.content: Where any ship or other property is seized under this Part and subsequently released to the owner, whether on the order of a court or otherwise, the owner or person in lawful possession may within 6 months of such release apply to the District Court or the Court of First Instance for compensation for any loss arising out of the seizure, which shall be recoverable as a civil debt due from the Government, and such application may be begun by motion. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: An award of compensation under subsection (1) shall be an award of such sum, if any, as is just and equitable in all the circumstances of the case, including the conduct and comparative blameworthiness of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner of the ship or other property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person in charge or control of the ship or other property at the time it was seized;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the agents of the persons specified in paragraphs (a) and (b); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: public officers and any other persons concerned.

section.name: s37I
section.heading: Entry of ships with unauthorized entrants may be permitted in certain circumstances

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding anything in this Part, no offence is committed, and no ship shall be liable to forfeiture, under this Part in respect of the presence of an unauthorized entrant on board a ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: which the Chief Executive has in his discretion on special grounds granted permission to enter Hong Kong; or (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whose first port of call is Hong Kong, if the unauthorized entrant was taken on board without reward pursuant to a legal obligation to go to his assistance.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings for an offence under this Part or for forfeiture arising out of such an offence, until it is proved that an unauthorized entrant was taken on board a ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without reward;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: pursuant to a legal obligation to go to the assistance of the unauthorized entrant; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whose first port of call was Hong Kong,

subsection.continued: the contrary shall be presumed.

def.name: LegalObligation
def.leadIn: For the purposes of this section legal obligation (法律義務) means an obligation imposed upon the state where the ship is registered, pursuant to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea signed in London on 1 November 1974, or any convention that replaces that Convention or any successor convention, as amended from time to time and as applicable to Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other international convention as applicable to Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: customary international law. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section Hong Kong is the first port of call of a ship if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: immediately before the ship first went to the assistance of any unauthorized entrants it was in the course of a business or commercial voyage and the next port of call at which the ship was due to call was Hong Kong; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: immediately after going to the assistance of the unauthorized entrants the ship proceeded directly to Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: it is necessary for the ship to enter Hong Kong as a port of refuge because there is a risk to the ship’s safety arising from weather conditions or from the carriage of hazardous cargoes together with unauthorized entrants or because the lives of the crew or other persons on board the ship are in danger;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the captain, owner or agent informs the Director of Marine at the earliest practicable opportunity of such of the circumstances specified in subparagraph (i) as apply to the ship; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the Secretary for Security in his discretion grants permission for the ship to enter Hong Kong.

section.name: s37J
section.heading: Prosecution for acts outside Hong Kong
section.content: Without prejudice to any law or enactment to the like or a similar effect as that of this section, where any person is in Hong Kong, he may be charged and convicted in respect of anything which was done or which occurred wholly or partly outside Hong Kong that would have been an offence under this Part if it had been done or had occurred within Hong Kong.

subsection.content: If in any proceedings under this Part a person is alleged to be, and there are reasonable grounds for believing that such person may be, an unauthorized entrant, that person shall be presumed to be such in the absence of evidence to the contrary. (Replaced 48 of 1992 s. 12)

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is charged with an offence under this Part as being, and there are reasonable grounds for believing that such person may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner of a ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the agent of the owner of a ship; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a member of the crew of a ship,

subsection.continued: that person shall be presumed to be such owner, agent or member, as the case may be, in the absence of evidence to the contrary. (Replaced 82 of 1993 s. 9)

section.name: s37L
section.heading: Secretary for Justice to consent to prosecution
section.content: No prosecution shall be brought under this Part without the consent of the Secretary for Justice.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: appeal (上訴) means an appeal made under section 37ZR;
Appeal Board (上訴委員會) means the Torture Claims Appeal Board established by section 37ZQ;

def.name: Claimant
def.leadIn: claimant (聲請人) means a person whose torture claim (not being a torture claim that has been withdrawn)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is not yet finally determined; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is a substantiated claim;

subsection.def: Convention (《公約》) means the United Nations Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment adopted by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 10 December 1984 as applied to Hong Kong;
finally determined (最終裁定)—see section 37V;
non-refoulement protection (免遣返保護), in relation to a claimant, means protection under Article 3 of the Convention against expulsion, return or extradition of the claimant to a torture risk State;
removal (遣離) means the removal of a person from Hong Kong under section 18 or under a removal order or a deportation order;

def.name: RevocationDecision
def.leadIn: revocation decision (撤銷決定) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a decision made by an immigration officer under section 37ZL(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a decision made by the Appeal Board under section 37ZM(1);

subsection.def: State (國家) means a country other than China;
subsequent claim (後繼聲請) means a torture claim by a person who has previously made a torture claim that has been finally determined or withdrawn;

def.name: SubstantiatedClaim
def.leadIn: substantiated claim (已確立聲請) means a torture claim—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is accepted as substantiated under section 37ZI(1)(a) and in respect of which no revocation decision has been made by an immigration officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in respect of which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a decision rejecting the claim under section 37ZI(1)(b) was made but reversed on appeal to the Appeal Board and no revocation decision has been made by the Appeal Board; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a revocation decision was made by an immigration officer but reversed on appeal to the Appeal Board;

subsection.def: surrender (移交) means the surrender of a person to a place outside Hong Kong under the Fugitive Offenders Ordinance (Cap. 503), and surrender proceedings (移交逃犯法律程序) means proceedings instituted for such surrender;

def.name: Torture
def.leadIn: torture (酷刑) means an act by which severe pain or suffering, whether physical or mental, is intentionally inflicted on a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for such purposes as—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: obtaining from that person or a third person information or a confession;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: punishing that person for an act which that person or a third person has committed or is suspected of having committed; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: intimidating or coercing that person or a third person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for any reason based on discrimination of any kind,

def.continued: when such pain or suffering is inflicted by, or at the instigation of, or with the consent or acquiescence of, a public official or other person acting in an official capacity, excluding pain or suffering arising only from, inherent in or incidental to lawful sanctions;

subsection.def: torture claim (酷刑聲請) means a claim for non-refoulement protection in Hong Kong on the ground of a torture risk made under section 37X or treated as having been made by virtue of section 37ZP(2)(b), including a torture claim re-opened under section 37ZE(2) or 37ZG(3);
torture claim form (酷刑聲請表格) means the torture claim form specified by the Director under section 37Y(4);
torture risk (酷刑風險) means the danger of being subjected to torture;

torture risk State (存在酷刑風險國家), in relation to a claimant, means a State in respect of which the claimant has made a torture claim on the ground that the claimant would be in danger of being subjected to torture in that State;
withdrawn (撤回), in relation to a claim, means withdrawn in accordance with section 37ZE or treated as withdrawn under section 37ZF or 37ZG.

subsection.content: In this Part, a reference to this Part includes Schedule 1A and any subsidiary legislation made under section 37ZW.

section.name: s37V
section.heading: When torture claim is finally determined

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2), (3), (4) and (5), a torture claim is finally determined once a decision on the claim is made by an immigration officer under section 37ZI.

subsection.leadIn: For a torture claim rejected by a decision under section 37ZI(1)(b), the claim is finally determined—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when the period within which an appeal may be lodged against the decision has expired (if an appeal against the decision has not been lodged within that period); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: when a notice to withdraw the appeal under section 37ZTA is received by the Appeal Board or the appeal has been disposed of (if an appeal has been lodged against the decision). (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 7)

subsection.content: If a revocation decision is made by an immigration officer in respect of a substantiated claim, the claim must, on and from the making of that decision, be treated as not yet finally determined.

subsection.leadIn: For a torture claim covered by subsection (3), the claim is finally determined—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when the period within which an appeal may be lodged against the revocation decision has expired (if an appeal against the revocation decision has not been lodged within that period); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: when a notice to withdraw the appeal under section 37ZTA is received by the Appeal Board or the appeal has been disposed of (if an appeal has been lodged against the revocation decision). (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 7)

subsection.content: If a revocation decision is made by the Appeal Board in respect of a substantiated claim, the claim must be treated as finally determined on the making of that decision.

section.name: s37W
section.heading: Restrictions on persons claiming non-refoulement protection in Hong Kong

subsection.leadIn: A person may claim non-refoulement protection in Hong Kong only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person is subject or liable to removal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apart from a torture risk State, the person does not have a right of abode or right to land in, or right to return to, any other State in which the person would be entitled to non-refoulement protection.

subsection.content: A person whose surrender is requested in surrender proceedings may claim non-refoulement protection in Hong Kong even if the person does not meet the descriptions in paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (1).

A person who claims non-refoulement protection in Hong Kong on the ground of a torture risk must signify to an immigration officer in writing the person’s intention to seek non-refoulement protection.

The written signification must give a general indication of the person’s reasons for claiming non-refoulement protection in Hong Kong, being reasons that relate to an act falling within the meaning of torture as defined by section 37U(1).
On signifying an intention under subsection (1), the person must allow an immigration officer or an immigration assistant to take the person’s fingerprints and photograph.
A torture claim is made when subsections (1), (2) and (3) have been complied with by the person making the claim.
A torture claim may be made only in respect of a person’s removal or surrender to a place outside China.

subsection.leadIn: A claimant must, on written request by an immigration officer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: complete a torture claim form, and the completed form must—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: state the grounds of the claim and the facts supporting the claim; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: include such other information as is required by the form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: return the torture claim form so completed to an immigration officer at an address specified in the form, together with all documents supporting the claim that are readily available to the claimant when the form is returned.

subsection.leadIn: The claimant must return the completed torture claim form in accordance with subsection (1)(b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within the period of 28 days after a written request under subsection (1) is given to the claimant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within any further period that an immigration officer allows under subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on an application made by a claimant in writing before the expiry of a period for returning a completed torture claim form in respect of the claimant’s torture claim; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: on being satisfied that the claimant—

subparagraph.content: has exercised, or had exercised, all due diligence to return a completed torture claim form within the period; but
will not be able to, or failed to, return a completed form within the period because of circumstances beyond the claimant’s control, (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 8)

subsection.continued: allow a further period that the immigration officer considers appropriate for the claimant to return the completed form.

subsection.content: The torture claim form is to be in a form specified by the Director.

section.name: s37Z
section.heading: Effect of making a torture claim

subsection.content: A claimant may not be removed from Hong Kong to a torture risk State.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), the making of a torture claim does not—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.leadIn: preclude the Government from liaising with any party (including a torture risk State) after—

subparagraph.content: the torture claim is rejected under section 37ZI;
a revocation decision under section 37ZL(1) is made in relation to the torture claim; or
the torture claim is withdrawn,

paragraph.continued: for the purpose of making arrangements for the removal of the claimant. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: To avoid doubt, it is declared that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a claimant may be removed, in accordance with section 24 or 25, to a specified place that is not a torture risk State;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a person whose torture claim—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is withdrawn; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: is not a substantiated claim on final determination,

paragraph.continued: may be removed, in accordance with section 24 or 25, to a specified place whether or not the specified place was alleged to be a torture risk State. (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 26)

subsection.leadIn: It is the duty of a claimant to substantiate a torture claim, and to this end, the claimant must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide to the Director and (on an appeal) to the Appeal Board all information relevant to the claim and make prompt and full disclosure of all material facts in support of the claim, including any document supporting those facts;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: comply with every requirement, procedure and condition (including any time limit)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: prescribed by this Part; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: required or specified by any person under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: A claimant must provide to the Director and (on an appeal) to the Appeal Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the claimant’s residential address in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the claimant’s correspondence address in Hong Kong (if different from the residential address),

subsection.continued: and must notify the Director and (on an appeal) the Appeal Board in writing of any change in either of those addresses as soon as practicable after the change.

subsection.content: A claimant must attend an interview at the date, time and place specified by an immigration officer in the written request referred to in section 37Y(1) to provide information and answer questions relating to the claimant’s torture claim.
The date of the interview must be a date after the expiry of the period for returning the completed torture claim form under section 37Y(2)(a).

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an immigration officer allows, under section 37Y(3), a further period for returning the completed torture claim form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date of the original interview specified in the written request is within the further period,

subsection.continued: the officer must change it to a date after the expiry of the further period.

subsection.content: A claimant must also attend any further interview required by an immigration officer at the date, time and place specified by the officer.

section.name: s37ZAC
section.heading: Language used for communications
section.content: An immigration officer may direct a claimant to communicate in a language that the officer reasonably considers the claimant is able to understand and communicate in.

subsection.content: After a completed torture claim form is returned by a claimant, an immigration officer may require the claimant to provide the immigration officer with any information or evidence related to the claimant’s torture claim that the immigration officer specifies. (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 11)
Information or evidence required to be provided to an immigration officer under subsection (1) must be provided within the time specified by the immigration officer. (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 11)

subsection.leadIn: If the physical or mental condition of the claimant is in dispute and is relevant to the consideration of a torture claim—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an immigration officer or (on an appeal) the Appeal Board may require the claimant to undergo a medical examination to be conducted by a medical practitioner as arranged by an immigration officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an immigration officer may, at the request of the claimant, arrange for a medical examination of the claimant to be conducted by a medical practitioner.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (1), the claimant must give any consent that is necessary to enable a medical examination to be arranged or conducted. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 12)

If a medical examination is arranged under subsection (1), the claimant must undergo the examination at the date, time and place specified by the immigration officer and notified to the claimant in writing.

A claimant must disclose to an immigration officer and (on an appeal) the Appeal Board the full medical report of any examination arranged for the claimant under this section within 3 working days after a request for the disclosure is made by the officer or the Board.

subsection.leadIn: If a claimant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with subsection (1A), (2) or (3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: fails to provide sufficient evidence in writing to satisfy an immigration officer or the Appeal Board that the claimant—

subparagraph.content: had exercised all due diligence to comply with the subsection concerned; but
failed to comply with the subsection concerned because of circumstances beyond the claimant’s control,

subsection.continued: the officer or the Board may decide not to take into account the disputed physical or mental condition of the claimant. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 12)

subsection.leadIn: In considering a torture claim, an immigration officer or the Appeal Board may take into account, as damaging the claimant’s credibility, the following behaviour of the claimant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any behaviour that the immigration officer or the Appeal Board considers is designed to, or is likely to be designed to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: conceal information;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: mislead; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: obstruct or delay the handling or determination of the claimant’s torture claim;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a failure to take advantage of a reasonable opportunity to claim non-refoulement protection in respect of a torture risk State while in a place outside Hong Kong to which the Convention applies (other than a torture risk State);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the claimant is a person who is subject or liable to removal, a failure to make the claim when, or as soon as practicable after—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the claimant has become subject or liable to removal; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the events on which the claim is based have taken place,

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if the claimant is a person whose surrender is requested in surrender proceedings, a failure to make the claim when, or as soon as practicable after—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: it comes to the claimant’s notice that the surrender proceedings have been commenced; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the events on which the claim is based have taken place,

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: a failure to make the claim before being arrested or detained under a provision of this Ordinance, unless—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the claimant had no reasonable opportunity to make the claim before the arrest or detention; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the claim relies wholly on matters arising after the arrest or detention.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1)(a), behaviour described in any of the following paragraphs is behaviour within the meaning of that subsection—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the production of a false document as proof of the claimant’s identity;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a failure, without reasonable excuse, to produce a document as proof of the claimant’s identity on request by an immigration officer;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: a failure, without reasonable excuse, to provide the information or evidence required by an immigration officer under section 37ZB(1); (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 13)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: a failure, without reasonable excuse, to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: attend an interview as required by section 37ZAB; or (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 13)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: provide information or answer any question put by an immigration officer at such an interview; (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 13)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a failure, without reasonable excuse, to make a full disclosure of the material facts in support of the torture claim, including any document supporting those facts, before the date of the first interview that the claimant is required by section 37ZAB to attend; (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 13)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: a failure, without reasonable excuse, to—

subparagraph.content: give consent as required by section 37ZC(1A);
undergo a medical examination as required by section 37ZC(2); or

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: a failure, without reasonable excuse, to comply with any requirement, procedure or condition (including any time limit)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: prescribed by this Part; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: required or specified by any person under this Part.

subsection.content: This section does not prevent an immigration officer or the Appeal Board from taking into account any other behaviour of the claimant as damaging the claimant’s credibility.

section.name: s37ZE
section.heading: Withdrawal of torture claim by claimant

subsection.content: A claimant may, before a torture claim is decided under section 37ZI, withdraw the claim by notifying an immigration officer in writing.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 37ZF(3), a torture claim that has been withdrawn under subsection (1) may be re-opened if the person who made the claim provides sufficient evidence in writing to satisfy an immigration officer that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: since the withdrawal, there has been a change of circumstances that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: could not reasonably have been foreseen by the person when the person gave the notification under subsection (1); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: when taken together with the material previously submitted for the claim, could increase the prospect of success of the claim; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by reason of special circumstances, it would be unjust not to re-open the claim.

subsection.content: If an immigration officer decides to re-open a person’s torture claim under subsection (2), the immigration officer must, by written notice, inform the person of the decision.

subsection.leadIn: If an immigration officer decides not to re-open the person’s torture claim, the immigration officer must, by written notice, inform the person of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reasons for the decision; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person’s right under section 37ZR to appeal against the decision.

subsection.content: If a torture claim is re-opened under subsection (2), subject to subsections (6) and (7), processing of the claim is to continue in accordance with this Part as if the claim had not been withdrawn.

If the period for returning a completed torture claim form in respect of a torture claim under section 37Y(2) has not expired at the time the claim is withdrawn under subsection (1), section 37Y(2) applies to the claim as if for paragraph (a) of that section there were substituted—

paragraph.content: within the period of 28 days after the notice under section 37ZE(3) is given to the claimant; or”.

subsection.leadIn: If a completed torture claim form in respect of the torture claim is not returned in accordance with section 37Y(2) as read with subsection (6), the claim is to be treated as withdrawn under section 37ZG(1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the expiry of the 28-day period; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a further period is allowed under section 37Y(3), on the expiry of the further period.

section.name: s37ZF
section.heading: Deemed withdrawal of torture claim on claimant’s departure

subsection.content: A torture claim (whether a claim pending final determination or a substantiated claim) made by a claimant who is subject or liable to removal must be treated as withdrawn if the claimant (for whatever reason) leaves Hong Kong.
A torture claim that is treated as withdrawn under subsection (1) must not be re-opened.

If a person leaves Hong Kong after the person has given notice to withdraw a torture claim under section 37ZE(1), the claim must be treated as having been withdrawn under subsection (1) and must not be re-opened.

section.name: s37ZG
section.heading: Deemed withdrawal of torture claim on failure to return completed torture claim form

subsection.content: A torture claim must be treated as withdrawn if the person who made the claim fails to return a completed torture claim form as required under section 37Y(2).

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer must give the person who made the claim a written notice stating that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the torture claim is treated as withdrawn under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person may apply to re-open the claim under subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: A torture claim treated as withdrawn under subsection (1) may be re-opened if the person who made the claim provides sufficient evidence in writing to satisfy an immigration officer that the person— (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 14)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: had exercised all due diligence to return a completed torture claim form as required under section 37Y(2); but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: failed to return a completed form as required under the section because of circumstances beyond the person’s control. (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 14)

subsection.leadIn: If an immigration officer decides to re-open a person’s torture claim under subsection (3), the immigration officer must, by written notice, inform the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of the decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the person is required to return a completed torture claim form in respect of the claim to an immigration officer at an address specified in the form within 14 days after the notice is given.

subsection.leadIn: If an immigration officer decides not to re-open the person’s torture claim, the immigration officer must, by written notice, inform the person of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the reasons for the decision; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person’s right under section 37ZR to appeal against the decision.

subsection.content: If a torture claim is re-opened under subsection (3), subject to subsections (7) and (8), processing of the claim is to continue in accordance with this Part as if the claim had not been withdrawn.
Section 37Y(2) applies to the torture claim as if for paragraph (a) of that section there were substituted—

paragraph.content: within the period of 14 days after the notice under section 37ZG(4) is given to the claimant; or”.

subsection.leadIn: If a completed torture claim form in respect of the torture claim is not returned in accordance with section 37Y(2) as read with subsection (7), the claim is to be treated as withdrawn under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the expiry of the 14-day period; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a further period is allowed under section 37Y(3), on the expiry of the further period.

section.name: s37ZH
section.heading: Order in which claims are processed
section.content: The Director may decide the order in which torture claims are to be processed, and no determination on a torture claim is to be called into question on the basis that it ought to have been processed earlier or later than any other torture claim or category of torture claims.

subsection.leadIn: Unless a torture claim is withdrawn, an immigration officer is to decide whether to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: accept the claim as substantiated; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: reject the claim.

subsection.leadIn: A decision may be made by an immigration officer under subsection (1) even if a claimant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has failed to attend an interview as required by section 37ZAB;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has failed to comply with section 37ZC(1A), (2) or (3); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has otherwise failed to proceed with the claim in accordance with this Part. (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 15)

subsection.content: A torture claim must be accepted as substantiated if there are substantial grounds for believing that the claimant would be in danger of being subjected to torture if the claimant were removed or surrendered to a torture risk State.
A torture claim must be rejected in the absence of substantial grounds for the belief referred to in subsection (3). (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 15)

subsection.leadIn: In determining whether there are substantial grounds for the belief referred to in subsection (3), all relevant considerations are to be taken into account, including, where applicable, the following matters in relation to the conditions in the torture risk State—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether there is a consistent pattern of gross, flagrant or mass violations of human rights in the torture risk State; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether there is any region within the torture risk State in which the claimant would not be in danger of being subjected to torture.

section.name: s37ZJ
section.heading: Immigration officer to notify decision on torture claim

subsection.content: After an immigration officer has decided to accept, or reject, a torture claim under section 37ZI(1)(a) or (b), the immigration officer must, by written notice, inform the claimant of the decision.

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer must, in a notice given under subsection (1) in respect of a decision rejecting a torture claim, also inform the claimant of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the reasons for the decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the claimant’s right under section 37ZR to appeal against the decision.

subsection.content: Without limiting any other power conferred by this Ordinance, a claimant may be detained under the authority of the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration or any assistant director of immigration pending final determination of the claimant’s torture claim. (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 16)

subsection.leadIn: The detention of a claimant under this section is not unlawful by reason of the period of the detention if that period is reasonable having regard to all the circumstances that justify its length, including—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: whether the manpower and financial resources allocated for carrying out the work involved in making such final determinations are such that it is reasonable to take the time it is taking, or has taken, to have the claimant’s torture claim finally determined;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: whether the making of—

subparagraph.content: a decision by an immigration officer under section 37ZI;
a revocation decision; or
a decision by the Appeal Board in relation to an appeal made under section 37ZR,

paragraph.continued: is directly or indirectly prevented or delayed by any action or lack of action of the claimant;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: whether the claimant poses, or is likely to pose, a threat or security risk to the community; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: factors that are not within the control of the Director. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 16)

section.name: s37ZL
section.heading: Revocation of immigration officer’s decision to accept torture claim

subsection.content: An immigration officer may, on a ground for a revocation decision specified in section 37ZN, revoke a decision made by an immigration officer under section 37ZI(1)(a) accepting a torture claim as substantiated.

subsection.leadIn: An immigration officer must give the claimant written notice of a proposed revocation, and the notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state the reasons for the proposed revocation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: state that the claimant may, within 14 days after the notice is given, inform the immigration officer by written notice of the claimant’s objection to the proposed revocation and the reasons for the objection (objection notice).

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the claimant has not given an objection notice in accordance with subsection (2)(b) and an immigration officer decides to make a revocation decision under subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after having considered the claimant’s objection notice, an immigration officer decides to make a revocation decision under subsection (1),

subsection.continued: the immigration officer must give the claimant written notice of the revocation decision, reasons for the revocation decision and the claimant’s right under section 37ZR to appeal against the revocation decision.

section.name: s37ZM
section.heading: Revocation of Appeal Board’s decision to reverse decision rejecting torture claim

subsection.content: On an application made by an immigration officer, the Appeal Board may, on a ground for a revocation decision specified in section 37ZN, revoke its decision that reversed a decision made by an immigration officer under section 37ZI(1)(b) rejecting a torture claim.

subsection.leadIn: Before making an application under subsection (1), an immigration officer must give the claimant written notice of the intended application, and the notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state the reasons for the intended application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: state that the claimant may, within 14 days after the notice is given, inform the immigration officer by written notice of the claimant’s objection to the intended application and the reasons for the objection (objection notice).

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the claimant has not given an objection notice in accordance with subsection (2)(b) and an immigration officer decides to make an application under subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after having considered the claimant’s objection notice, an immigration officer decides to make an application under subsection (1),

subsection.continued: the immigration officer must make the application by filing with the Appeal Board a notice of application in a form specified by the Chairperson of the Appeal Board.

subsection.content: As soon as practicable after the filing of a notice of application, an immigration officer must serve on the claimant a copy of the notice of application.

section.name: s37ZN
section.heading: Grounds for revocation decision
section.leadIn: A ground specified in any of the following paragraphs is a ground for a revocation decision mentioned in section 37ZL(1) or 37ZM(1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any information or evidence submitted in support of the claim is false or misleading and the false or misleading information or evidence is material to the substantiation of the claim;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: the torture risk giving rise to the claim has ceased to exist;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: having regard to the prevailing circumstances, the claim should not be accepted as substantiated. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 17)

subsection.content: Except as provided in subsection (2), a person who has previously made a torture claim must not subsequently make another torture claim.

subsection.leadIn: A person may make a subsequent claim if the person provides sufficient evidence in writing to satisfy an immigration officer that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there has been a significant change of circumstances since the previous claim was finally determined or withdrawn; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the change, when taken together with the material previously submitted in support of the previous claim, would give the subsequent claim a realistic prospect of success.

subsection.content: In deciding whether or not a person may make a subsequent claim under subsection (2), an immigration officer may take into account any finding of credibility or fact made by an immigration officer or the Appeal Board in relation to a torture claim previously made by the person.
If an immigration officer decides that a person may make a subsequent claim under subsection (2), the immigration officer must give the person written notice of the decision.

If an immigration officer decides that a person may not make a subsequent claim under subsection (2), the immigration officer must give the person written notice of the decision, and the notice must also include the reasons for the decision.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a subsequent claim must be made in accordance with section 37X but despite section 37X(4), a subsequent claim is not made unless section 37ZO(2) is complied with; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all of the other provisions of this Part apply to a subsequent claim as they apply to any other torture claim.

subsection.leadIn: If a subsequent claim is made by a person whose removal is pending following a decision under section 37ZI(1)(b) rejecting the person’s previous torture claim (including such a decision confirmed by the Appeal Board on an appeal against the decision), or following a revocation decision in respect of the person’s previous torture claim—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 37X(1), (2), (3) and (4) does not apply in relation to the subsequent claim;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the subsequent claim is taken to be made on the day when a notice under section 37ZO(4) is given notifying the person the subsequent claim may be made; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the purposes of this Part, section 37Y is taken to have been complied with in respect of the subsequent claim.

subsection.content: In determining a subsequent claim, an immigration officer and (on an appeal) the Appeal Board may take into account any finding of credibility or fact made by an immigration officer or the Appeal Board in relation to a torture claim previously made by the person making the subsequent claim.
A board to be known as the “Torture Claims Appeal Board” is established.

subsection.leadIn: The function of the Appeal Board is to hear and determine—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an appeal made under section 37ZR; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application for a revocation decision under section 37ZM.

section.name: s37ZR
section.heading: Appeal
section.leadIn: A person aggrieved by a decision of an immigration officer may appeal to the Appeal Board if the decision is made in respect of the person under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 37ZE(4) or 37ZG(5) (decision not to re-open a torture claim);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 37ZI(1)(b) (decision rejecting a torture claim); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 37ZL(1) (revocation decision made by an immigration officer).

subsection.content: A person who wishes to appeal against a decision referred to in section 37ZR must file with the Appeal Board a notice of appeal within 14 days after notice of the decision is given to the person unless late filing of the notice is allowed by the Board under section 37ZT(3).

subsection.leadIn: A notice of appeal must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in a form specified by the Chairperson of the Appeal Board; (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 18)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: duly completed and signed; and (Added 7 of 2021 s. 18)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: accompanied by a copy of the notice of the decision being appealed against.

subsection.content: No action may be taken in relation to a notice of appeal that does not comply with subsection (2)(a) or (ab). (Added 7 of 2021 s. 18)

On receiving a notice of appeal referred to in subsection (3), the Appeal Board must, by written notice, inform the person filing the notice of the non-compliance and that no further action will be taken in relation to the notice. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 18)

section.name: s37ZT
section.heading: Late filing of notice of appeal

subsection.leadIn: If a notice of appeal is filed after the expiry of the 14-day period referred to in section 37ZS(1), it must include an application for late filing of the notice, which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must include a statement of the reasons for failing to file the notice within that period; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be accompanied by all available evidence relied on in support of the reasons referred to in paragraph (a). (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 19)

subsection.content: The Appeal Board must decide, as a preliminary decision without a hearing, whether the Board allows the late filing of the notice of appeal under subsection (3), and in doing so, the Board may only take account of the statement of reasons stated in the application for late filing of the notice of appeal and the evidence relied on in support of the reasons. (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 19)

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board may allow the late filing of the notice of appeal if the person filing the notice provides sufficient evidence in writing to satisfy the Board that the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: had exercised all due diligence to file the notice within the period specified in section 37ZS(1); but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: failed to file the notice within the period because of circumstances beyond the person’s control. (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 19)

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (3), the fact that a person attempted to file one or more notices of appeal that do not comply with section 37ZS(2)(a) or (ab), whether within the period specified in section 37ZS(1) or otherwise, must not be taken as evidence that the person had exercised all due diligence to file a notice of appeal within the period. (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 19)
If the Appeal Board allows the late filing of the notice of appeal, it must, by written notice to the person filing the notice, inform the person of the Board’s decision. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 19)

subsection.leadIn: If the Appeal Board does not allow the late filing of the notice of appeal, it must, by written notice to the person filing the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inform the person that the Board refuses the notice as it is filed out of time; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give reasons for the refusal. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 19)

subsection.content: A person who has filed a notice of appeal under section 37ZS (or section 37ZT if late filing is allowed) may, at any time before the Appeal Board determines the appeal, withdraw the appeal by filing a written notice with the Board.
An appeal against a decision is withdrawn once a notice to withdraw the appeal is received by the Appeal Board and no further notice of appeal may be filed in relation to the decision.

section.name: s37ZU
section.heading: Practice and procedure of Appeal Board
section.content: Schedule 1A has effect with respect to the Appeal Board and its members and to the proceedings of, and procedural and other matters concerning, the Appeal Board.

subsection.leadIn: A notice or other document (howsoever described) required to be served or given (howsoever described) by the Director, an immigration officer or the Appeal Board on or to another person under this Part may be served on or given to that other person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: personally;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: by leaving it for the person, or by sending it by post addressed to the person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if the person is a claimant, at the last known residential or correspondence address provided by the claimant to the Director or the Appeal Board under section 37ZA(2); or

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: if the person is held in custody, detained or imprisoned, by leaving it for the person, or by sending it by post addressed to the person, at the place where the person is held in custody, detained or imprisoned; or (Added 7 of 2021 s. 21)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the person is acting by a legal representative, by leaving it for the legal representative, or by sending it by post addressed to the legal representative, at the place of business or correspondence address of the legal representative.

subsection.leadIn: A notice or other document served or given in the manner described in subsection (1), other than by sending it by post, is conclusively presumed to have been served or given and received at the following time—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if it is served on or given to the person personally, when it is so served or given; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it is left at a place or an address, on the second working day after it was so left. (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 21)

subsection.content: A notice or other document served or given by sending it by post in the manner described in subsection (1) is presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to have been served or given and received on the second working day after it was so sent.

section.name: s37ZW
section.heading: Regulations
section.leadIn: The Secretary for Security may by regulation provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any matter in relation to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the making or processing of a torture claim;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the making of a decision on a torture claim (whether or not a subsequent claim);

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the withdrawal or re-opening of a torture claim; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: a revocation decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the procedure for the extension of any period allowed under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the practice and procedure of the Appeal Board; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: generally for the better carrying out of the purposes of this Part.

section.name: s37ZX
section.heading: Claimant of substantiated claim may apply for permission to take employment etc.

subsection.content: The Director may, on an application of a claimant who has a substantiated claim, permit the claimant to take employment or establish or join in a business.
A permission must not be given under subsection (1) unless the Director is satisfied that exceptional circumstances exist that justify such a permission being given to the claimant.

subsection.leadIn: A permission given under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be given subject to a time limit and any other condition the Director thinks fit to impose; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be given in writing.

subsection.leadIn: A permission given under this section expires immediately on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the expiry of the time limit (if any); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the breach of any other condition,

subsection.continued: subject to which the permission is given.

subsection.content: The Director may, before a permission expires under subsection (4), vary any time limit or any other condition imposed under subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: To avoid doubt, a permission given under this section is not and must not be taken as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a limit of stay or other condition of stay imposed or varied under section 11; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Director’s authority under section 13 for the claimant to remain in Hong Kong.

section.name: s37ZY
section.heading: Claimant not ordinarily resident in Hong Kong
section.content: Without limiting section 2(4), a person must not be treated as ordinarily resident in Hong Kong for the purposes of this Ordinance during any period in which the person remains in Hong Kong only by virtue of the person’s torture claim (whether or not the person is a claimant who has a substantiated claim and whether or not permission has been given to the person under section 37ZX).

subsection.content: Schedule 4 provides for the savings and transitional arrangements that apply on, or relate to, the commencement* of the Immigration (Amendment) Ordinance 2012 (23 of 2012). (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 22)
Schedule 5 provides for the savings and transitional arrangements that apply on, or relate to, the commencement# of the Immigration (Amendment) Ordinance 2021 (7 of 2021). (Added 7 of 2021 s. 22)

section.name: s38
section.heading: Prohibition of landing and remaining without permission, and penalty for carrying illegal immigrant

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), a person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being a person who by virtue of section 7 may not land in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant, lands in Hong Kong without such permission; or (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: having landed in Hong Kong unlawfully, remains in Hong Kong without the authority of the Director,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 4 and to imprisonment for 3 years. (Amended 75 of 1990 s. 3; L.N. 25 of 1996)

subsection.content: A person may land in Hong Kong, without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant, for the purpose of examination under section 4(1)(a) or for the purpose of verification of identity by an automated means provided under section 4A in accordance with arrangements in that behalf approved by the Director, and if he submits himself forthwith to such examination or verification of identity shall be deemed for the purposes of subsection (1) not to have landed unless and until permission to land is granted to him. (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10; 6 of 2005 s. 4)

The Chief Executive may by order provide that subsection (1) shall not apply to an immigrant who lands from a ship or aircraft in such circumstances as may be specified in the order. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: If a person lands from a ship in contravention of subsection (1)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the captain of the ship; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the owner of the ship and his agent,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $600,000 and to imprisonment for 7 years; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine of $600,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years, (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)

subsection.continued: unless he proves that all reasonable steps had been taken to ensure that persons did not land from the ship in contravention of subsection (1).

section.name: s38AA
section.heading: Prohibition of taking employment and establishing business, etc.

subsection.leadIn: A person—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in respect of whom a removal order or a deportation order is in force;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: who, having been given permission to land in Hong Kong under section 11(1), remains in Hong Kong in breach of the limit of stay imposed under section 11(2) in relation to the permission; or (Added 7 of 2021 s. 23)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: who was refused permission to land in Hong Kong under section 11(1), (Added 7 of 2021 s. 23)

subsection.continued: must not take any employment, whether paid or unpaid, or establish or join in any business. (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 23)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply to a person if the person has the Director’s permission under section 37ZX to take employment or establish or join in a business. (Added 23 of 2012 s. 8)
A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

section.name: s38A
section.heading: Site controller commits offence if illegal immigrant on construction site, etc.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: ConstructionWork
def.leadIn: construction work (建築工程) has the same meaning as in the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59) but does not include redecoration, renovation, alteration, maintenance or repair of domestic premises by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an occupier of the premises; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an owner of the premises if that is the only premises owned by him in the building which contains the premises;

subsection.def: domestic premises (住用處所) means premises used or intended to be used solely or principally for residential purposes and constituting a separate household unit.

subsection.content: Where it is proved that a person to whom section 38(1) applies was on a construction site, the construction site controller of that construction site commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $350,000. (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)

It is a defence in proceedings for an offence under subsection (2) for the person charged to prove that he took all practicable steps to prevent persons to whom section 38(1) applies from being on the construction site. (Amended 6 of 1999 s. 3)

Where it is proved that a person, who is not lawfully employable by virtue of section 17G(2), has committed an offence under section 41 by taking employment on a construction site, the construction site controller of that construction site commits an offence and is liable to a fine of $350,000. (Added 6 of 1999 s. 3)

It is a defence in proceedings for an offence under subsection (4) for the construction site controller charged to prove that he took all practicable steps to prevent persons who are not lawfully employable from taking employment on the construction site. (Added 6 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: Where a construction site controller is charged with an offence under subsection (4), a certificate purporting to be signed by the Director and certifying that the person concerned who has committed an offence under section 41 by taking employment on a construction site was, at the date of the alleged offence, not lawfully employable, shall be admitted in evidence on its production without further proof and, until evidence to the contrary is adduced, it shall be presumed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the certificate was signed by the Director; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the person concerned who has committed an offence under section 41 by taking employment on a construction site was, at the date of the alleged offence, not lawfully employable. (Added 6 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.content: Section 17G shall apply to this section as it applies to Part IVB. (Added 6 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s39
section.heading: Liability of captain of ship carrying persons seeking to land unlawfully
section.leadIn: If a person on board a ship is seeking to land from the ship in contravention of section 38(1)(a), the captain of the ship shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $600,000 and to imprisonment for 7 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine of $600,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years, (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)

section.continued: unless he proves that he did not know and had no reason to suspect that such person was seeking to land in contravention of section 38(1)(a).

section.name: s40
section.heading: Aircraft passengers arriving without valid travel document
section.content: If a passenger who arrives in Hong Kong in an aircraft does not have a valid travel document, the owner of the aircraft and his agent shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 6.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Breach of condition of stay
section.content: Any person who contravenes a condition of stay in force in respect of him shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s42
section.heading: False statements, forgery of documents and use and possession of forged documents

subsection.leadIn: Any person who makes or causes to be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to an immigration officer, immigration assistant or any other person lawfully acting under or in the execution of Part IB, II, III, IV or VIIC of this Ordinance; (Amended 23 of 2012 s. 9)

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: for the purpose of obtaining, whether for himself or any other person, any travel document, certificate of entitlement, entry permit, re-entry permit, certificate of identity, document of identity, APEC business travel card, travel pass or Vietnamese refugee card,

subsection.continued: any statement or representation which he knows to be false or does not believe to be true shall be guilty of an offence. (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 10)

subsection.leadIn: Any person who—

paragraph.name: a

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: alters without lawful authority or forges; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: transfers to another without reasonable excuse,

paragraph.continued: any travel document, certificate of entitlement, entry permit, re-entry permit, certificate of identity, document of identity, APEC business travel card, travel pass or Vietnamese refugee card or any document whatsoever issued, kept or made under or for the purposes of Part IB, II, III or IV of this Ordinance; (Replaced 61 of 1986 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: uses for the purposes of Part IB, II, III, IV or VIIC of this Ordinance any forged, false or unlawfully obtained or altered travel document, certificate of entitlement, entry permit, re-entry permit, certificate of identity, document of identity, APEC business travel card, travel pass, Vietnamese refugee card or other document;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: has in his possession—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any forged, false or unlawfully obtained or altered travel document, certificate of entitlement, entry permit, re-entry permit, certificate of identity, document of identity, APEC business travel card, travel pass or Vietnamese refugee card; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any forged, false or unlawfully altered document whatsoever intended for use for the purposes of Part IB, II, III, IV or VIIC of this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence. (Amended 23 of 2012 s. 9)

subsection.content: A travel document, certificate of entitlement, entry permit, re-entry permit, certificate of identity, document of identity, APEC business travel card, travel pass or Vietnamese refugee card shall be deemed to be unlawfully obtained for the purposes of this section if any person made a false statement or representation for the purposes of or in connection with an application for the issue or renewal of the same.

subsection.leadIn: Any person who is guilty of an offence under this section shall be liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to a fine of $150,000 and to imprisonment for 14 years; and (Amended 66 of 1981 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)

subsection.def: In this section, false (虛假) means false in a material particular and forged (偽造) has the meaning assigned to that term by Part IX of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200). (Amended 49 of 1992 s. 5)

section.name: s43
section.heading: Breach of deportation order, and landing from ship or aircraft in which removal to be effected

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any person in respect of whom a deportation order is in force is in Hong Kong in contravention of the order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person who has been placed on board a ship or aircraft under section 25(3) lands from the ship or aircraft before it leaves Hong Kong,

subsection.continued: he shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for 7 years; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: A person who has not been given notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of a deportation order made against him;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of the rescission of a suspension of the deportation order made against him,

subsection.continued: shall not be guilty of an offence under subsection (1)(a).

section.name: s43A
section.heading: Disrupting proceedings of Torture Claims Appeal Board
section.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, disrupts the proceedings of the Torture Claims Appeal Board established by section 37ZQ commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Miscellaneous offences
section.leadIn: Any person who without reasonable excuse knowingly contravenes—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any requirement made under section 3(2), 5(1), (3), (6) or (7), 6(3), 11(8) or 15(1);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any directions given under section 5(8), 24(1) or 25(2); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any condition imposed under section 13,

section.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine of $120,000.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Continuance of an offence
section.content: Where a person is convicted of an offence under section 44 consisting of a contravention of section 14(1) and the contravention continues after the conviction, then, unless he has a reasonable excuse for the continuance of the contravention, he shall be guilty of a further offence under section 44 and shall be liable on conviction to be punished accordingly.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Limitation of time for prosecution of summary offences

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a complaint may be made or an information laid in respect of an offence under this Ordinance punishable only on summary conviction within 2 years from the time when the matter of such complaint or information respectively arose.
A complaint may be made or an information laid in respect of an offence under section 38(1)(b) or 41 within 3 years from the time when the matter of such complaint or information respectively arose.

section.name: s46A
section.heading: Forfeiture of property other than a ship or vehicle

subsection.content: An application may at any time be made by the Secretary for Justice to a magistrate in the prescribed form, or in accordance with rules of court to the District Court or the Court of First Instance by motion, for forfeiture under subsection (2) of any property other than a ship or vehicle. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: If in the course of a prosecution for an offence under section 38(1) or under section 90(1) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) where the arrestable offence which a person has committed is an offence under section 38(1), or of the hearing of an application made under subsection (1) by the Secretary for Justice for forfeiture under this section, it appears to the court that any property other than a ship or vehicle— (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been, is being or is intended to be used in the commission or to procure or facilitate the commission of such an offence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is the proceeds or represents the proceeds directly or indirectly (as being the result of any disposal or realization of the whole or part of the proceeds) of any such offence,

subsection.continued: the court shall, whether or not any person is convicted of any such offence, order the forfeiture of such property unless it is satisfied that it would not be just to do so or that there is other good reason why it should not do so.

subsection.content: Where it appears to a court which is considering making an order for forfeiture under this section that a person who is not before the court may claim ownership of, or an interest in, the property which may be forfeited, it shall give that person an opportunity to make representations to the court as to why such an order should not be made.

section.name: s46B
section.heading: Power to restrain disposal of property

subsection.content: A court, in the course of a prosecution under this Ordinance, or of the hearing of any application by the Secretary for Justice for forfeiture under this Ordinance, may of its own motion or upon application by the Secretary for Justice, by written notice to any person in possession or control of money or property that may be forfeited, direct that such person shall not dispose of or otherwise deal with the property specified in the notice without the consent of the court. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

A person who disposes of, or otherwise deals with property specified in a notice under subsection (1) other than in accordance with the consent of the court shall be guilty of an offence and liable to a fine at level 5 or the value of the property disposed of or otherwise dealt with, whichever is the greater, and to imprisonment for 3 years. (Amended L.N. 25 of 1996)

Where the captain of a ship is guilty of an offence under section 38(4) or 39, the ship shall be liable to forfeiture, whether or not the captain is convicted in respect of such offence. (Amended 42 of 1979 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: Any vehicle which has been used in the commission of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence under section 38(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offence under section 90(1) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) where the arrestable offence which a person has committed is an offence under section 38(1) of this Ordinance,

subsection.continued: shall be liable to forfeiture, whether or not any person has been convicted in respect of such offence.

content.leadIn: Within 21 days of the seizure of any ship or vehicle which appears to him to be liable to forfeiture under subsection (1) or (2), the Director may serve notice of such seizure on the owner of the ship or vehicle:
content.proviso: Provided that where there is more than one owner of a ship or vehicle it shall be sufficient for the purposes of this subsection to give notice to one of the owners.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (3) shall be deemed to have been duly served if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is delivered to the person on whom it is to be served;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is sent by registered post addressed to such person at the place of residence or business of such person, if any, known to the Director; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where it cannot be served in accordance with paragraph (a) or (b), the notice is exhibited in the Immigration Department in a place to which the public have access for a period of not less than 7 days commencing within 21 days of the seizure of the ship or vehicle.

subsection.leadIn: Within 7 days after the service under subsection (3) of a notice of seizure, notice of the seizure of the ship or vehicle shall be published—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the Gazette; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in 1 newspaper published in Hong Kong in the English language and in 1 newspaper so published in the Chinese language.

subsection.leadIn: Where a notice of seizure has been served under subsection (3), any person who has a claim (hereinafter referred to as the claimant) may within 30 days after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the notice, if it was served under subsection (4)(a) or (b); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the first day on which the notice was exhibited, if it was served under subsection (4)(c),

subsection.continued: give notice in writing to the Director that he claims that the ship or vehicle is not liable to forfeiture.

subsection.content: If, on the expiry of the appropriate period of time specified in subsection (6) for the giving of a notice of claim, no such notice has been given in writing to the Director, the ship or vehicle shall be forfeited forthwith to the Government. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: A person has a claim for the purposes of this section and section 48 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is the owner of the ship or vehicle or the agent of the owner; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he was in possession of the ship or vehicle at the time it was seized.

subsection.content: Where a notice of claim is given under section 47(6), the Director shall apply in the prescribed form to a magistrate for the forfeiture of the ship or vehicle and shall state in the application the name and address of the claimant as specified in the notice of claim.

When any such application is made to a magistrate, the magistrate shall issue a summons in the prescribed form to the claimant, requiring him to appear before a magistrate on the hearing of the application, and shall cause a copy of the summons to be served on the Director.

subsection.leadIn: If, on the hearing of an application under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: neither the claimant nor any other person appears before the magistrate to make a claim and the magistrate is satisfied that the summons was duly served; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: neither the claimant nor any other person satisfies the magistrate that he has a claim,

subsection.continued: and the magistrate is satisfied that the ship or vehicle is liable to forfeiture, the magistrate shall order that the ship or vehicle be forfeited to the Government. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: If, on the hearing of an application under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person satisfies the magistrate that he has a claim; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the magistrate is satisfied that the ship or vehicle is liable to forfeiture,

subsection.continued: the magistrate may order that the ship or vehicle be—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: forfeited to the Government; or (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: delivered to the owner thereof or his agent.

subsection.content: If, on the hearing of an application under this section, the magistrate is not satisfied that the ship or vehicle is liable to forfeiture, he shall order that it be delivered to the owner thereof or his agent.

On the hearing of an application under this section a certified true copy of the record of the proceedings, including the decision of the court, in any proceedings in respect of the offence under section 38(1) or (4) or 39 of this Ordinance or section 90(1) of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) shall be admissible in evidence. (Replaced 42 of 1979 s. 5)

Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, an application under this section shall be deemed for the purposes of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) to be a complaint to which section 8 of that Ordinance applies.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Security in lieu of detention where application made for forfeiture of ship or vehicle

subsection.content: Where an application has been made under section 48, a magistrate may, on payment into court by way of security of a sum of money not less in amount than the value of the ship as assessed by the Director of Marine or the value of the vehicle as assessed by the Director, order that the ship or vehicle be delivered to the claimant, subject to a condition that it be re-delivered into the custody of the Director before the date of hearing of the application.

If a ship or vehicle which has been delivered to a claimant under subsection (1) is not re-delivered to the Director before the date of hearing of the application under section 48, the magistrate hearing the application may, in lieu of ordering that the ship or vehicle be forfeited to the Government, order that the money paid into court under subsection (1) be forfeited to the Government. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

Save as provided in subsection (2), the magistrate hearing the application shall, at the conclusion of the proceedings, order that the amount of the money paid into court under subsection (1) shall be repaid to the person who paid it into court.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Claims for return of forfeited ships, vehicles or money

subsection.leadIn: The owner of any ship or vehicle forfeited to the Government under section 47 or 48 or his agent or the person by whom money forfeited to the Government under section 49 was paid into court may within 6 weeks after— (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the determination of any appeal against the order for its forfeiture,

subsection.continued: give notice in writing to the Director of his intention to submit to the Chief Executive a moral claim in respect of the forfeited ship, vehicle or money.

subsection.leadIn: Where the owner of a forfeited ship or vehicle or the person by whom forfeited money was paid into court has given notice in writing to the Director under subsection (1) and has submitted a moral claim to the Chief Executive by lodging it with the Chief Secretary for Administration within 1 month from the date of such notice, the Chief Executive may— (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order the return of the forfeited ship or vehicle to the owner or his agent or the return of the forfeited money to the person by whom it was paid into court, as the case may be; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: direct that the claim be referred to the Chief Executive in Council.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council, on considering a claim referred to him under subsection (2), may— (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order the return of the forfeited ship or vehicle to the owner or his agent or the return of the forfeited money to the person by whom it was paid into court, as the case may be; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: reject the claim.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Public officers to be subject to Chief Executive’s directions

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may give such directions as he thinks fit (either generally or in any particular case) with respect to the exercise or performance by any public officer, not being a judge, a district judge or a magistrate, of any powers, functions or duties under this Ordinance.
