Any public officer shall, in the exercise or performance of any powers, functions or duties under this Ordinance, comply with any directions given by the Chief Executive under subsection (1).

section.name: s52
section.heading: Immigration officers to be subject to directions of Director of Immigration

subsection.content: The Director of Immigration may give such directions as he thinks fit (either generally or in any particular case) with respect to the exercise or performance by any other immigration officer or an immigration assistant of any powers, functions or duties under this Ordinance. (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 11)

Any immigration officer or immigration assistant shall, in the exercise or performance of any powers, functions or duties under this Ordinance, comply with any directions given by the Director of Immigration under subsection (1) in addition to complying with directions given by the Chief Executive under section 51(1). (Amended 57 of 1972 s. 11)
Directions given under subsection (1) shall not be inconsistent with directions given by the Chief Executive under section 51(1).

section.name: s53
section.heading: Review of decisions of public officers

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (8), any person aggrieved by a decision, act or omission of any public officer taken, done or made in the exercise or performance of any powers, functions or duties under this Ordinance may by notice in writing lodged with the Chief Secretary for Administration within the time prescribed in subsection (2) object to that decision, act or omission. (Amended 62 of 1980 s. 8; L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.leadIn: An objection under subsection (1) shall be lodged within the period hereinafter specified after the person aggrieved was informed of the decision, act or omission or the same became known to him (whichever is the earlier), that is to say—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: within 24 hours, in the case of a person who, having landed in Hong Kong unlawfully, has been in Hong Kong in the opinion of the Director for less than 10 days; (Amended 75 of 1981 s. 9)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within 14 days, in any other case.

subsection.content: An objection under subsection (1) by a person referred to in subsection (2)(a) shall be considered by the Chief Executive; any other objection under subsection (1) shall be considered by the Chief Executive in Council.

On consideration of an objection under subsection (1), the Chief Executive or the Chief Executive in Council, as the case may be, may confirm, vary or reverse the decision, act or omission of the public officer or substitute therefor such other decision or make such other order as he thinks fit.

The Chief Executive in Council may at any time of his own motion vary or reverse any decision, act or omission of any public officer taken, done or made in the exercise or performance of any powers, functions or duties under this Ordinance or substitute therefor such other decision or make such other order as he thinks fit.

Nothing in this section entitles a person to object under this section to any decision, act or omission of the Chief Executive, the Chief Executive in Council or any court or entitles the Chief Executive in Council to review any decision, act or omission of a court.

For the removal of doubt, it is hereby declared that the lodging of an objection does not give the person by whom or on whose behalf it is lodged the right of abode in Hong Kong or right to land or remain in Hong Kong pending the decision on the objection of the Chief Executive or the Chief Executive in Council. (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 21)

subsection.leadIn: No objection shall be made under this section—

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: to non-acceptance of an application under section 2AB(3) or section 2AC(3); (Added 124 of 1997 s. 6)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: to the decision of the Director on an application under section 2AB(6) or 2AC(6); (Added 124 of 1997 s. 6)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to a removal order made by the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration or any assistant director of immigration; or (Amended 8 of 1998 s. 4)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to the decision of an adjudicator; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to the decision of a public officer in respect of the right of abode in Hong Kong of any person where the Registration of Persons Tribunal has previously determined that that person does not enjoy that right; or (Replaced 31 of 1987 s. 21. Amended 23 of 1989 s. 5)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to any decision in respect of which a right to apply to a Board under section 13F(1) has at any time subsisted; or (Added 23 of 1989 s. 5)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to an order for the removal of a person from Hong Kong under section 13E; or (Added 23 of 1989 s. 5. Amended 52 of 1991 s. 5)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to a decision to transfer, from one detention centre to another, a person detained under section 13D(1); or (Added 52 of 1991 s. 5. Amended 23 of 2012 s. 11)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: to a decision made by an immigration officer—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: under section 37ZE(4) or 37ZG(5) not to re-open a torture claim that has been withdrawn;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under section 37ZI(1)(b) to reject a torture claim;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: under section 37ZL(1) to revoke a decision accepting a torture claim as substantiated;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: under section 37ZO(5) not to allow a subsequent claim to be made by a person who has previously made a torture claim; or (Added 23 of 2012 s. 11)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: to any decision made in the performance of a function of the Torture Claims Appeal Board under Part VIIC. (Added 23 of 2012 s. 11)

section.name: s53A
section.heading: Appeal against removal orders made by Director or Deputy Director of Immigration

subsection.leadIn: A person against whom a removal order has been made by the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration or any assistant director of immigration may appeal to the Tribunal against the removal order on the ground that on the facts of his case— (Amended 8 of 1998 s. 4)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: he enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong; or (Added 31 of 1987 s. 22)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: he has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA; or (Added 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he had at the date when the removal order was made the permission of the Director of Immigration to remain in Hong Kong.

content.leadIn: A person who wishes to appeal under subsection (1) shall serve written notice of appeal, stating his grounds of appeal and the facts upon which he relies, upon an immigration officer or immigration assistant, within 24 hours of being notified of the removal order under section 19(5):
content.proviso: Provided that such notice shall not preclude such person from raising other facts prior to the determination of his appeal by the Tribunal and relying upon those facts.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Tribunal, upon an examination of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the written notice of appeal served under subsection (2) on which a person (the appellant) appealing under subsection (1) seeks to rely; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the summary or record of the proceedings of the Registration of Persons Tribunal in respect of an unsuccessful appeal by the appellant under section 3D(1) of the Registration of Persons Ordinance (Cap. 177),

subsection.continued: is satisfied that the facts or matters on which the appellant is seeking to rely are the same or substantially the same facts or matters on which the appellant sought to rely on the appeal to the Registration of Persons Tribunal, it may dismiss the appeal under subsection (1) without a hearing and shall cause written notice of such dismissal to be given or sent by post to the appellant. (Added 31 of 1987 s. 22)

section.name: s53B
section.heading: Removal orders not to be executed pending appeal
section.leadIn: A person shall not be removed pursuant to a removal order made by the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration or any assistant director of immigration— (Amended 8 of 1998 s. 4)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: until the time limited for an appeal has passed or the person against whom the removal order has been made declares in writing that he does not intend to appeal, whichever is the sooner; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where an appeal against the order is commenced, until the appeal is determined by the Tribunal, or the appellant declares in writing that he is abandoning his appeal, whichever is the sooner.

section.name: s53C
section.heading: Dismissal of appeal without hearing
section.leadIn: Where the Tribunal, upon an examination of the written grounds of appeal on which a person appealing under section 53A seeks to rely, is satisfied that the facts or matters on which the appellant is seeking to rely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: would not entitle the appellant to succeed in the appeal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: are the same or substantially the same facts or matters on which the appellant sought to rely on an unsuccessful appeal under section 53A,

section.continued: it may dismiss the appeal without a hearing and in any such case it shall cause written notice of such dismissal to be given to the appellant and to the Director of Immigration.

subsection.leadIn: On an appeal under section 53A against a removal order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where the Tribunal determines that on the facts of the case as it finds them the appellant—

subparagraph.name: ia
subparagraph.content: does not enjoy the right of abode in Hong Kong; and (Added 31 of 1987 s. 23)

subparagraph.name: ib
subparagraph.content: does not have the right to land under section 2AAA; and (Added 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: does not, disregarding the effect of the removal order under section 19(4), have the permission of the Director of Immigration to remain in Hong Kong,

paragraph.continued: it shall dismiss the appeal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, subject to subsection (3), it shall allow the appeal and rescind the removal order. (Amended 124 of 1997 s. 7)

subsection.content: The decision of the Tribunal under this section or section 53C shall be final.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal shall not allow an appeal on the ground that the appellant enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong by virtue of being a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 1 unless the appellant’s status as such a permanent resident has been established by his holding of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a valid travel document issued to him and of a valid certificate of entitlement also issued to him and affixed to such travel document;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a valid HKSAR passport issued to him; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a valid permanent identity card issued to him. (Added 124 of 1997 s. 7)

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings before the Tribunal, a certificate purporting to be signed by the Director and certifying that a person does not hold a valid certificate of entitlement shall be admitted in evidence without further proof and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: until the contrary is proved it shall be presumed that the certificate was signed by the Director; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the certificate shall be prima facie evidence of the fact contained in it. (Added 124 of 1997 s. 7)

section.name: s53E
section.heading: Release of successful appellant
section.content: Where an appeal under section 53A is successful the appellant shall be released forthwith unless he may be held in lawful custody on some other matter.

section.name: s53F
section.heading: Establishment of Immigration Tribunal

subsection.content: There is hereby established a tribunal to be known as the Immigration Tribunal.

For the purpose of exercising the jurisdiction of the Tribunal, the Chief Executive shall appoint a chief adjudicator, deputy chief adjudicator and such number of other adjudicators as from time to time may be necessary.
The remuneration, if any, of the chief adjudicator, deputy chief adjudicator and other adjudicators shall be determined by the Chief Executive.

section.sourceNote: (Added 62 of 1980 s. 9. Amended 24 of 1984 s. 3; 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.leadIn: The practice and procedure on appeals under section 2AD or 53A, and of the Tribunal shall be such as shall be prescribed, and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing and of section 59, the following matters may be prescribed and provided for under section 59— (Amended 124 of 1997 s. 8)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of adjudicators who shall hear and determine any appeal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provision as to witnesses and the production of documents similar to that in sections 21 and 22 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227);

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: provision for the payment of an allowance to witnesses at a hearing of an appeal similar to that contained in rules made under section 9B of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) for the payment of an allowance to witnesses in criminal proceedings before any court; (Added 24 of 1984 s. 4)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the hearing of an appeal in the absence of the appellant where he cannot attend by reason of illness or injury or where his attendance would present a threat to the health or safety of other persons at the hearing or in other circumstances; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: provision empowering the Tribunal to allow, if it thinks fit, the appellant and respondent to be represented by counsel or a solicitor.

subsection.content: The Tribunal and any adjudicator may in the discharge of any function under this Ordinance consult any member of a panel of legal advisers to the Tribunal appointed by the Secretary for Justice. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)
The proceedings before the Tribunal may be conducted in the English or Chinese language or both as the Tribunal thinks fit. (Added 51 of 1995 s. 11)

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding subsection (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any party to proceedings in the Tribunal may address the Tribunal in any language;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any witness in proceedings in the Tribunal may testify in any language;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a legal representative in any proceedings may use either or both of the official languages. (Added 51 of 1995 s. 11)

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may suspend the deportation order made against any person on such conditions as he thinks fit, and during the continuance of the suspension the deportation order shall not be in force. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

The Chief Executive may rescind the suspension of a deportation order, whereupon the deportation order shall again be in force in respect of the person against whom it was made. (Amended 82 of 1993 s. 13; 21 of 2024 s. 78)
Any police officer who has reason to suspect that a person has contravened any condition subject to which the deportation order made against that person is suspended may arrest such person.
If a person who has been arrested under subsection (3) is charged with any offence, he shall be brought before a magistrate within 48 hours after his arrest.

The Chief Executive may rescind the deportation order made against any person, but the rescission of the deportation order shall not affect the power of the Chief Executive to make another such order against that person.

The Chief Executive may, on rescinding the deportation order made against any person, require that person to enter into a recognizance in the prescribed form in such amount and with such sureties as the Chief Executive may specify. (Amended 55 of 1983 s. 3)

A requirement under subsection (2) shall be deemed for the purposes of the provisions of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) relating to recognizances to be an order under section 61(1) of that Ordinance.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Miscellaneous powers of immigration officers and immigration assistants

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, an immigration officer or immigration assistant may— (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 8)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: board and search any ship, aircraft, vehicle or train which has arrived in Hong Kong (not being a ship of war or a military aircraft);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: search any person being examined under section 4(1), other than a person who enjoys the right of abode in Hong Kong, or has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 2AAA, and any property belonging to such person or under his control; (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 24; 88 of 1997 s. 19; 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: seize, remove and detain any thing which may be forfeited under this Ordinance or which is or contains evidence of the commission of an offence under this Ordinance or of the landing of any person in Hong Kong unlawfully; (Amended 75 of 1981 s. 10)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: search any person who is or has been or may be arrested or detained under this Ordinance and any property belonging to him or under his control.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, an immigration officer or immigration assistant may— (Amended 31 of 1984 s. 12)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: detain for not more than 7 days any document—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: produced pursuant to a requirement under section 5(6)(b); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: found on any person searched under subsection (1)(b);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: arrest and detain any person if he has reason to suspect that such person has committed an offence under this Ordinance, or has landed in Hong Kong unlawfully and has not been authorized by the Director to remain; (Amended 75 of 1981 s. 10)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: board and search any ship, aircraft, vehicle or train (not being a ship of war or a military aircraft) if he has reason to suspect that there is therein— (Amended 68 of 1995 s. 55)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any person who may be arrested under this Ordinance; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any thing which may be seized under this Ordinance; (Added 15 of 1980 s. 8. Amended E.R. 2 of 2018)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: enter and search any premises or place if he has reason to suspect that there is therein any person who may be arrested under this Ordinance; (Added 68 of 1995 s. 55)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: without a warrant where it would not be reasonably practicable to obtain one, enter and search any premises or place if he has reason to suspect that there is therein any thing which may be seized under this Ordinance. (Added 68 of 1995 s. 55)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, any public officer may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: break open any outer or inner door of or in any premises or place which he is empowered to enter and search;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: stop and forcibly board any ship, aircraft, vehicle or train which he is empowered to board and search;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: stop any person whom he is empowered to search;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: remove by force any person or thing obstructing any arrest, boarding, entry, search, seizure, removal or detention which he is empowered to make;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: detain every person found in any premises or place which he is empowered to search until the same has been searched;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: detain every person on board any ship, aircraft, vehicle or train which he is empowered to search, and prevent any person from approaching or boarding such ship, aircraft, vehicle or train, until it has been searched.

subsection.content: No person shall be searched under this section except by a person of the same sex and no person shall be searched under this section in a public place if he objects to being so searched. (Amended 67 of 1995 s. 91(2))

Where a document is detained under subsection (1A)(a), the person by whom it was produced or on whom it was found shall be supplied with a photographic copy of such document if he so requests and makes payment therefor, and the copy so supplied to a person shall be made in his presence. (Amended 31 of 1984 s. 12)

section.name: s56AA
section.heading: Warrant for entry and search, etc.

subsection.content: Whenever it appears to a magistrate upon the oath of any person that there is reasonable cause to suspect that there is in any premises or place any thing which may be seized under this Ordinance, such magistrate may by warrant directed to any member of the Immigration Service or any police officer empower such member or officer with such assistants as may be necessary by day or by night to enter and if necessary to break into or forcibly enter the premises or place named in the warrant and there to search for and seize, remove and detain any such thing which may be seized under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Whenever it appears to a magistrate upon the oath of any person that there is reasonable cause to suspect that there is in any building, vessel (not being a ship of war or a ship having the status of a ship of war) or place any document, or any portion or extract therefrom, or any other article or chattel which is likely to be of value (whether by itself or together with anything else) to the investigation of any offence that has been committed, or that is reasonably suspected to have been committed or to be about to be committed or to be intended to be committed against the provisions of this Ordinance, such magistrate may by warrant directed to any member of the Immigration Service or any police officer empower such member or officer with such assistants as may be necessary by day or by night— (Amended 53 of 1996 s. 10)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enter and if necessary to break into or forcibly enter such building, vessel or place and to search for and take possession of any such document or portion of or extract therefrom or any such other article or chattel which may be found therein; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to detain, during such period as is reasonably required to permit such a search to be carried out, any person who may appear to have such document or portion thereof or extract therefrom or other article or chattel in his possession or under his control and who, if not so detained, might prejudice the purpose of the search.

section.name: s56A
section.heading: Exercise by customs officers of certain powers of immigration officers

subsection.content: Any member of the Customs and Excise Service authorized in writing by the Commissioner of Customs and Excise may exercise the powers conferred on an immigration officer by section 3(2), 4(1), 5(3), (6) or (7), 11(1), (1A) or (2), 18(1)(a), 24(1)(a) or (3), 27, 32(1) or 56(1) or (1A).

An authorization given by the Commissioner of Customs and Excise under subsection (1) may be given to a member of the Customs and Excise Service by name or may be given to any such member holding such rank or performing such duties as the Commissioner may specify, and may extend to all the powers specified in subsection (1) or to such of those powers as the Commissioner may specify.

The Commissioner of Customs and Excise may, after consultation with the Director of Immigration, give such directions as the Director may specify to members of the Customs and Excise Service authorized under this section to exercise any of the powers of an immigration officer.

A member of the Customs and Excise Service shall, in the exercise of any powers which he is authorized under this section to exercise, comply with any directions given by the Commissioner of Customs and Excise under subsection (3) in addition to complying with directions given by the Chief Executive under section 51(1). (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)
Directions given under subsection (3) shall not be inconsistent with directions given by the Chief Executive under section 51(1). (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

The Commissioner of Customs and Excise may, after consultation with the Director of Immigration, cancel any authorization given under subsection (1) and, in the event of such cancellation, any directions given by the Commissioner under subsection (3) shall cease to have effect.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: Commissioner of Customs and Excise (海關關長) includes a Deputy Commissioner of Customs and Excise and an Assistant Commissioner of Customs and Excise; (Amended 40 of 1985 s. 8; 18 of 2014 s. 81)
member of the Customs and Excise Service (海關人員) means any person holding an office specified in Schedule 1 to the Customs and Excise Service Ordinance (Cap. 342).

section.name: s57
section.heading: Exercise by police officers of certain powers of immigration officer

subsection.content: Any police officer authorized in writing by the Commissioner of Police may exercise the powers conferred on an immigration officer by section 3(2), 4(1), 5(3), (6) or (7), 11(1), (1A) or (2), 18(1)(a), 24(1)(a) or (3), 27, 32(1) or 56(1) or (1A). (Amended 66 of 1981 s. 4; 79 of 1982 s. 9)

An authorization given by the Commissioner of Police under subsection (1) may be given to a police officer by name or may be given to any police officer holding such rank or performing such duties as the Commissioner may specify, and may extend to all the powers specified in subsection (1) or to such of those powers as the Commissioner may specify.

The Commissioner of Police may, after consultation with the Director of Immigration, give such directions as the Director may specify to police officers authorized under this section to exercise any of the powers of an immigration officer.

A police officer shall, in the exercise of any powers which he is authorized under this section to exercise, comply with any directions given by the Commissioner of Police under subsection (3) in addition to complying with directions given by the Chief Executive under section 51(1). (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)
Directions given under subsection (3) shall not be inconsistent with directions given by the Chief Executive under section 51(1). (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.content: The Commissioner of Police may, after consultation with the Director of Immigration, cancel any authorization given under subsection (1) and, in the event of such cancellation, any directions given by the Commissioner under subsection (3) shall cease to have effect. (Added 31 of 1984 s. 14)

subsection.def: In this section, Commissioner of Police (警務處處長) includes any deputy commissioner of police, senior assistant commissioner of police or assistant commissioner of police.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Power to make regulations
section.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may make regulations for all or any of the following purposes— (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: providing for any matter or thing which is to be or may be prescribed under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the issue, in such form as the Director of Immigration may determine, of any document for the purposes of this Ordinance; (Replaced 21 of 1987 s. 3)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the fees payable in respect of the issue or renewal of documents issued by or on behalf of the Director of Immigration or in respect of visas or any other matters arising under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: generally for the better carrying out of the purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s59A
section.heading: Amendment of Schedule 1
section.content: The Legislative Council may by resolution amend Schedule 1.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Designation of approved immigration anchorages and approved landing places
section.content: The Secretary for Security may by order designate the places which shall be approved immigration anchorages and approved landing places for the purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Visa issued in respect of valid travel document and its holder

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2) and without prejudice to any other provision of this Ordinance, a document is not a valid travel document for the purposes of this Ordinance unless it bears, or its holder has obtained, a visa which was issued by or on behalf of the Director of Immigration and is in force on the date on which its holder arrives in Hong Kong. (Amended 13 of 2009 s. 6)
The Director of Immigration may exempt from subsection (1) any person or any class or description of person.

For any of the purposes of this Ordinance, if a person who by virtue of section 7 may not land or remain in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant does not produce an identity card relating to himself when required to do so by an immigration officer, immigration assistant or police officer, such person shall be deemed, until the contrary is proved, to have landed in Hong Kong unlawfully. (Amended 79 of 1982 s. 10)

subsection.leadIn: For any of the purposes of this Ordinance, if a person who by virtue of section 7 may not land in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant is on board a ship proceeding through the waters of Hong Kong, such person shall be deemed to be seeking to land in contravention of section 38(1)(a) unless it is proved that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he was a member of the crew of the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he was ordinarily resident in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he was in possession of a travel document, entry permit or re-entry permit; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the ship was leaving Hong Kong.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Evidence of certain acts under Ordinance

subsection.leadIn: Any document purporting to be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a removal order signed by the Chief Executive or by the Director of Immigration, the Deputy Director of Immigration or any assistant director of immigration, or a deportation order signed by the Clerk to the Executive Council; or (Replaced 62 of 1980 s. 10. Amended 8 of 1998 s. 4; 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of a removal order or a deportation order certified by the Chief Secretary for Administration or the Clerk to the Executive Council to be a true copy of the removal order or deportation order, (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.continued: shall be admitted in evidence in any proceedings on its production without further proof, and until the contrary is proved it shall be presumed that the removal order or deportation order was made against the person named and on the date specified therein. (Amended 14 of 1994 s. 24)

subsection.leadIn: A certificate purporting to be made for the purposes of this subsection and to set out—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a requirement made in writing under section 5(1), (3) or (7), 6(3) or 15(1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: directions given in writing under section 5(8) or 24(1); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any exemption granted under section 5(9), 11(9) or 14(2) to any class or description of persons,

subsection.continued: and purporting to be signed by the Director of Immigration shall be admitted in evidence in any proceedings on its production without further proof, and—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: until the contrary is proved, it shall be presumed that the certificate was signed by the Director of Immigration and that the requirement was made or the directions given to the person named and on the date specified in the certificate or that the exemption was granted and was in force on the date so specified, as the case may be; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the certificate shall be prima facie evidence of the requirement, directions or exemption.

subsection.leadIn: A certificate purporting to be made for the purposes of this subsection and to set out directions given in writing under section 25(2) and purporting to be signed by the Director of Immigration shall be admitted in evidence in any proceedings on its production without further proof, and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: until the contrary is proved, it shall be presumed that the certificate was signed by the Director of Immigration and that the directions were given to the person named and on the date specified in the certificate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the certificate shall be prima facie evidence of the directions.

section.name: s63A
section.heading: Evidence by certificate
section.leadIn: Where in any proceedings a person is charged with an offence under section 38(4), 38A or 39 or with aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring, or with conspiracy to aid, abet, counsel or procure, the commission by another of an offence under section 38(1), a certificate purporting to be signed by the Director and certifying that that or any other person— (Amended 61 of 1979 s. 8; 82 of 1993 s. 15)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: does not enjoy the right of abode in Hong Kong; (Added 31 of 1987 s. 25)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: does not have the right to land in Hong Kong under section 2AAA; (Added 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not a person who, by virtue of section 9(1) or 10(1), may land in Hong Kong without the permission of an immigration officer or immigration assistant; and (Amended 15 of 1980 s. 10)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has not been given permission to land in Hong Kong under section 11,

section.continued: shall be admitted in evidence on its production without further proof and—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: until the contrary is proved it shall be presumed that the certificate was signed by the Director; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the certificate shall be prima facie evidence of the facts contained therein.

section.name: s63B
section.heading: Admissibility of copies of records
section.leadIn: A document purporting to be a copy of the records or part of the records kept by the Director and purporting to be certified as a true copy thereof by the officer having custody of the records shall be admissible in evidence in criminal or civil proceedings before any court on its production without further proof and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: until the contrary is proved, the court before which such document is produced shall presume—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the document is certified by such officer; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that the document is a true copy of the records or part of the records to which it refers; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such document shall be prima facie evidence of all matters contained therein.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Burden of proving certain matters
section.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance or in any other proceedings under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any proceedings with reference to any act done or proposed to be done under this Ordinance,

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: is a Hong Kong permanent resident; (Amended 31 of 1987 s. 26)

paragraph.name: ia
paragraph.content: has been ordinarily resident in Hong Kong continuously for 7 years; (Added 122 of 1997 s. 4)

paragraph.name: ib
paragraph.content: is settled or has returned to settle in Hong Kong before 1 July 1997; (Added 122 of 1997 s. 4)

paragraph.name: ic
paragraph.content: has returned to settle in Hong Kong before 1 January 1999; (Added 122 of 1997 s. 4)

paragraph.name: id
paragraph.content: has not been absent from Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 36 months; (Added 122 of 1997 s. 4)

paragraph.name: ie
paragraph.content: was born in Hong Kong; (Added 122 of 1997 s. 4)

paragraph.name: if
paragraph.content: was a Hong Kong permanent resident before 1 July 1997; (Added 122 of 1997 s. 4)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: is not an alien;

paragraph.name: vaa
paragraph.content: is a Chinese citizen; (Added 122 of 1997 s. 4)

paragraph.name: vi
paragraph.content: has been ordinarily resident in Hong Kong for 3 years or more than 3 years;

paragraph.name: vii
paragraph.content: is exempt from any provision of this Ordinance or belongs to a class or description of persons who are exempt from any provision of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: vii
paragraph.content: is an alien to whom section 14(1) or 16(1) does not apply;

paragraph.name: ix
paragraph.content: is a person to whom section 38(1)(a) does not apply by virtue of an order under subsection (3) of that section,

section.continued: the onus of proving the same shall lie, subject to section 2AA(1), on that person.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Recovery of moneys due under recognizance
section.content: Any sum of money due under a recognizance entered into in accordance with a requirement under section 11(8) or 36(1) or (3) shall be recovered in the District Court as a debt due to the Government, notwithstanding that the amount is in excess of $20,000.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Transitional provisions
section.leadIn: Schedule 2 shall have effect for the purposes of transition to the provisions of this Ordinance from the provisions of the following Ordinances repealed by this Ordinance, namely— (Amended 78 of 1982 s. 12)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: Deportation of Aliens Ordinance (Cap. 240, Revised Edition 1964); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance (Cap. 243, Revised Edition 1964).

section.name: s67
section.heading: Transitional provisions in respect of Immigration (Amendment) Ordinance 1997
section.content: Schedule 3 shall have effect in connection with the abolition of the status of resident British citizen and resident United Kingdom belonger under the Immigration (Amendment) Ordinance 1997 (88 of 1997).

schedule.name: sch1
schedule.heading: Permanent Residents of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

subsection.leadIn: In this Schedule, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: Chinese citizen (中國公民) means a person of Chinese nationality under the Nationality Law of the People’s Republic of China, as implemented in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region pursuant to Article 18 of and Annex III to the Basic Law and interpreted in accordance with the Explanations of Some Questions by the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress Concerning the Implementation of the Nationality Law of the People’s Republic of China in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region adopted at the 19th meeting of the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress at the 8th National People’s Congress on 15 May 1996; (Replaced 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))
new born infant (初生嬰兒) means a child under the age of 12 months or a child who appears to the Director to be under the age of 12 months.

subsection.leadIn: The relationship of parent and child is taken to exist as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of a parent and child, between a person and a child born to such person in or out of wedlock; (Replaced L.N. 192 of 1999)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: of a parent and adopted child, between a parent and a child adopted only in Hong Kong under an order made by a Court in Hong Kong under the Adoption Ordinance (Cap. 290).

subsection.leadIn: For an abandoned new born infant found within Hong Kong,—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a new born infant, who appears to the Director to be of Chinese descent, is taken, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to be the legitimate child of a Chinese citizen who was a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region at the time of birth of the child;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a new born infant, who appears to the Director to be not of Chinese descent, is taken, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to be the legitimate child of a parent not of Chinese nationality who had the right of abode in Hong Kong under paragraph 2(d) at the time of birth of the child.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of calculating the continuous period of 7 years in which a person has ordinarily resided in Hong Kong, the period is reckoned to include a continuous period of 7 years—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: for a person under paragraph 2(d), before or after the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region but immediately before the date when the person applies to the Director for the status of a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

subsection.leadIn: A person is settled in Hong Kong if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is ordinarily resident in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he is not subject to any limit of stay in Hong Kong.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
section.leadIn: A person who is within one of the following categories is a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: A Chinese citizen born in Hong Kong before or after the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region. (Replaced L.N. 192 of 1999. Amended L.N. 84 of 2002)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: A Chinese citizen who has ordinarily resided in Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 7 years before or after the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: A person of Chinese nationality born outside Hong Kong before or after the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region to a parent who, at the time of birth of that person, was a Chinese citizen falling within category (a) or (b). (Replaced L.N. 192 of 1999)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: A person not of Chinese nationality who has entered Hong Kong with a valid travel document, has ordinarily resided in Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 7 years and has taken Hong Kong as his place of permanent residence before or after the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: A person under 21 years of age born in Hong Kong to a parent who is a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region in category (d) before or after the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region if at the time of his birth or at any later time before he attains 21 years of age, one of his parents has the right of abode in Hong Kong.

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: A person other than those residents in categories (a) to (e), who, before the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, had the right of abode in Hong Kong only.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of paragraph 2(d), the person is required—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to furnish information that the Director reasonably requires to satisfy him that the person has taken Hong Kong as his place of permanent residence. The information may include the following—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether he has habitual residence in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whether the principal members of his family (spouse and minor children) are in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: whether he has a reasonable means of income to support himself and his family;

subparagraph.name: iv

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to make a declaration in the form the Director stipulates that he has taken Hong Kong as his place of permanent residence; the declaration for a person under the age of 21 years must be made by one of his parents or by a legal guardian. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 16)

subsection.content: A person claiming to have the status of a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(d) does not have the status of a permanent resident in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region until he has applied to the Director and the application has been approved by the Director.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of paragraph 2(d), a person is taken to have entered Hong Kong on a valid travel document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if he entered Hong Kong before 1 July 1997 with an expired travel document or with a travel document that was not a valid travel document but was permitted to remain by an immigration officer or an immigration assistant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if he was born in Hong Kong and was permitted to remain in Hong Kong by an immigration officer or an immigration assistant.

subsection.content: For the purposes of paragraph 2(e), the person on attaining the age of 21 years ceases to be a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region and may apply to the Director for the status of a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(d) at any time.
Section 2AAA applies in relation to a person who ceases to have the status of a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under this paragraph. (Amended 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of paragraph 2(f), the person is required—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to furnish information that the Director may reasonably require to determine whether that person had the right of abode only in Hong Kong immediately before the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to make a declaration that he had the right of abode only in Hong Kong immediately before the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; the declaration for a person under the age of 21 years must be made by one of his parents or by a legal guardian.

subsection.content: If the person claims that he had no right of abode in a place that the Director reasonably believes that he had, the onus of proving that he did not have the right of abode in the place lies on the person.

A person under 21 years of age born in Hong Kong on or after 1 July 1997 to a parent who is a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(f) at the time of the birth of the person is taken to have the status of a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(f) if, but for this subparagraph, the person has no right of abode in any place including Hong Kong.

The person on attaining the age of 21 years ceases to be a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(f) and may apply to the Director for the status of a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(d) at any time.
Section 2AAA applies in relation to a person who ceases to have the status of a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under this paragraph. (Amended 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

subsection.leadIn: A person who is not of Chinese nationality and who was a permanent resident of Hong Kong before 1 July 1997 is taken to be a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under paragraph 2(d) and exempt from the requirements under paragraph 3 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he was settled in Hong Kong immediately before 1 July 1997;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after he ceased to be settled in Hong Kong immediately before 1 July 1997 he returns to settle in Hong Kong within the period of 18 months commencing on 1 July 1997; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: after he ceased to be settled in Hong Kong immediately before 1 July 1997 he returns to settle in Hong Kong after the period of 18 months commencing on 1 July 1997 but only if he has not been absent from Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 36 months.

subsection.content: A person who is a Chinese citizen and was a Hong Kong permanent resident immediately before 1 July 1997 under this Ordinance as then in force shall, as from 1 July 1997, be a permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region as long as he remains a Chinese citizen. (Replaced 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

section.name: s7
section.heading: Loss of the status as a permanent resident
section.leadIn: A permanent resident of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region loses the status of such resident only if— (Amended 28 of 1998 s. 2(2))

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being a person falling within the category in paragraph 2(d) or (e) has been absent from Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 36 months since he ceased to have ordinarily resided in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being a person falling within the category in paragraph 2(f), has been absent from Hong Kong for a continuous period of not less than 36 months after he obtained the right of abode in any place other than Hong Kong and has ceased to have ordinarily resided in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: In this Schedule—

def.name: Appeal
def.leadIn: appeal (上訴) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an appeal made under section 37ZR; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an application for a revocation decision under section 37ZM;

subsection.def: claimant (聲請人)—(a)in relation to an appeal made under section 37ZR, means the person who has lodged the appeal; and(b)in relation to an application for a revocation decision under section 37ZM, means the person who has been served with a notice of application under subsection (4) of the section; (Added 7 of 2021 s. 25)
member (委員) means a member of the Torture Claims Appeal Board established by section 37ZQ; (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 25)
notice of hearing (聆訊通知) means a notice of the date, time and place of a hearing served under section 13 of this Schedule. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subsection.content: An expression used in this Schedule has the same meaning as is given to it in section 37U.
In this Schedule, a reference to Part VIIC includes this Schedule and any subsidiary legislation made under section 37ZW.

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board comprises the following members appointed by the Chief Executive—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Chairperson;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at least one Deputy Chairperson; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a panel of persons whom the Chief Executive considers suitable for selection under section 6 of this Schedule for hearing and determining an appeal.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive may appoint a person as a member if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person was formerly a judge or magistrate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person is qualified to practise as a barrister, solicitor or advocate in a court in Hong Kong or a common law jurisdiction having unlimited jurisdiction either in civil or criminal matters, and has so practised for a period of or periods totalling not less than 5 years; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person, in the opinion of the Chief Executive, is suitably qualified to be a member.

subsection.content: Each appointment is for a term of not more than 3 years and a member may be re-appointed at the end of a term.
An appointment of a member is to be published in the Gazette.

If a person ceases to be a member at a time when the person is involved in the hearing or determination of an appeal, the person may continue to be involved in the appeal as if the person were a member until the appeal is disposed of.
A member may be paid remuneration and allowances at any rates determined by the Chief Executive.
A member may resign by notice in writing to the Chief Executive.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive may by notice in writing revoke the appointment of a member on the ground of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: neglect of duty, misconduct or bankruptcy;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: physical or mental incapacity that precludes the member from carrying out the member’s functions; or

subsection.continued: (c) any other sufficient cause.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Role of Chairperson
section.content: In addition to the Chairperson’s other functions, the Chairperson is responsible for making any arrangements that are practicable to ensure that members discharge their functions in an orderly and expeditious manner.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Deputy Chairperson to act in place of Chairperson

subsection.content: If the Chairperson is unable to act as Chairperson for any period by reason of illness, absence from Hong Kong or any other cause, a Deputy Chairperson is to act in the place of the Chairperson for that period.
If 2 or more persons are appointed as Deputy Chairpersons, the Chairperson may designate any one of them to act on behalf of the Chairperson during the period mentioned in subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: The Chairperson may delegate to a Deputy Chairperson any of the Chairperson’s powers and functions under the following provisions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 6 of this Schedule;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 7 of this Schedule;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 16 of this Schedule (but only in so far as it relates to giving directions in a particular case).

subsection.content: A delegation may be subject to any terms and conditions that the Chairperson considers appropriate.
The Chairperson may revoke a delegation.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Composition of Appeal Board for purposes of appeal

subsection.content: For hearing and determining an appeal, the Appeal Board is to consist of 1 member (who may or may not be the Chairperson) selected by the Chairperson for this purpose, except as provided in subsection (2).
Having regard to the circumstances of a particular appeal, the Chairperson may select 3 members to hear and determine the appeal.
In exercising the power under subsection (2), the Chairperson must nominate one of the 3 members to be the presiding member. (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 25)
A member who has a direct or indirect interest in an appeal must not take part in the hearing and determination of the appeal.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Order in which appeals are to be heard

subsection.content: The Chairperson may decide the order in which appeals and matters are to be heard or determined generally or in any particular circumstances.

No decision on an appeal or matter is to be called into question on the basis that the appeal or matter ought to have been heard or determined earlier or later than any other appeal or matter, or category of appeals or matters.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Notice of Appeal be served on Director

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the Appeal Board must, as soon as practicable after receiving a notice of appeal filed under section 37ZS(1), serve a copy of the notice on the Director.

If a notice of appeal under section 37ZS(1) is filed out of time, the Appeal Board is required to serve a copy of the notice on the Director only if it decides to allow late filing of the notice under section 37ZT(3), and in that event, the Board must serve the notice on the Director as soon as practicable after the decision is made.

subsection.leadIn: The Director must, as soon as practicable after receiving a copy of a notice of appeal served under section 8 of this Schedule, provide to the Appeal Board and the claimant— (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 25)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the decision being appealed against is a decision under section 37ZI(1)(b) rejecting a torture claim—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a copy of the completed torture claim form relating to the torture claim in respect of which the decision was made; and

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the decision being appealed against is a revocation decision of an immigration officer under section 37ZL(1)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a copy of the completed torture claim form relating to the torture claim in respect of which the decision was made;

subparagraph.name: ii
iii
iv
subparagraph.content: a copy of the notice of proposed revocation of the torture claim given under section 37ZL(2); and

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: a copy of the claimant’s objection notice (if any) referred to in section 37ZL(3)(b);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the decision being appealed against is a decision under section 37ZE(4) not to re-open a torture claim withdrawn by the claimant— (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a copy of any completed torture claim form relating to the torture claim;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a copy of the written record of any interview of the claimant conducted by an immigration officer in considering the torture claim;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a copy of the claimant’s notice withdrawing the claim; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: a copy of any evidence in writing provided by the claimant under section 37ZE(2); or (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 25)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if the decision being appealed against is a decision under section 37ZG(5) not to re-open a torture claim treated as withdrawn on the claimant’s failure to return a completed torture claim form— (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a copy of the written notice under section 37ZG(2) informing the claimant that the claim is treated as withdrawn; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a copy of any evidence in writing provided by the claimant under section 37ZG(3). (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: The Director must, as soon as practicable after filing with the Appeal Board a notice of application for a revocation decision under section 37ZM(3), provide to the Appeal Board and the claimant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the completed torture claim form relating to the torture claim in respect of which the application is made;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of the written record of any interview of the claimant conducted by an immigration officer in considering the torture claim;

paragraph.name: c
d
e
paragraph.content: a copy of the written notice under section 37ZM(2) informing the claimant of an intended application for a revocation decision to be made by the Board; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a copy of the claimant’s objection notice (if any) referred to in section 37ZM(2)(b).

section.name: s10
section.heading: Hearing to be in private
section.content: A hearing is to be held in private unless the Appeal Board directs that it be held in public.

subsection.content: The proceedings before the Appeal Board may be conducted in the English or Chinese language, or both, as the Board considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Appeal Board may direct a claimant to address the Board in a language that the Board reasonably considers the claimant is able to understand and communicate in; (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 25)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Appeal Board may direct a witness in proceedings before the Board to testify in a language that the Board reasonably considers the witness is able to understand and communicate in; and (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 25)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a legal representative in proceedings before the Appeal Board may use the English or Chinese language, or both.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Determination of appeal without a hearing
section.content: The Appeal Board may determine an appeal without a hearing if, having regard to the material before it and the nature of the issues raised, the Board is satisfied that the appeal can be justly determined without a hearing.

subsection.content: If the Appeal Board decides to hold a hearing, the Board must, not less than 28 days before the date of hearing, serve on the parties notice of the date, time and place of the hearing. (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 25)

Despite subsection (1), the Appeal Board may give less than 28 days’ notice to the parties if it considers appropriate to do so in a particular case, but in any event the notice period must not be less than 7 days. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: To avoid doubt, this section does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a hearing that is rescheduled under section 15(5) of this Schedule; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a further hearing of an appeal. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subsection.content: The Director need not attend a hearing unless required to do so by a notice of hearing.

If, having regard to the particular circumstances of an appeal, the Appeal Board considers that the Director’s attendance at the hearing of the appeal is necessary, the Board may, by the notice of hearing, require the Director to attend the hearing.
The Director may also attend a hearing on the Director’s own initiative.
If the Director intends to attend a hearing on the Director’s own initiative, the Director must notify the Appeal Board and the claimant in writing as soon as practicable of the intention.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Documents to be served on Appeal Board

subsection.content: The Director must, as soon as practicable after receiving a notice of hearing, serve on the Appeal Board, with a copy to the claimant, a bundle of all the documents relating to the torture claim concerned.

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board may require a party to file and serve on the Board, with a copy to the other party—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: statements of evidence that will be called at the hearing together with other information or evidence relating to the appeal that the Board considers necessary; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a list of witnesses whom the party wishes to call to give evidence.

subsection.content: The statements, information, evidence and list referred to in subsection (2) must be filed and served within the period specified by the Appeal Board. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 25)

If a claimant does not attend a hearing in person, irrespective of whether the claimant is represented at the hearing by a legal representative, the Appeal Board may hear the appeal in the absence of the claimant.

If a claimant referred to in subsection (1) wishes the Appeal Board to fix another hearing date for the appeal, the claimant must, within 3 working days after the date of the hearing, submit a written request to the Appeal Board to fix another hearing date.
The request must contain a written explanation of the claimant’s absence from the hearing together with all available evidence supporting the explanation.

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board must proceed to determine the appeal by making a decision under section 23(1) of this Schedule if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no request is made under subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: where a request is made under subsection (2), the Board is not satisfied, on the basis of the written explanation and supporting evidence submitted with the request, that the claimant—

subparagraph.content: had exercised all due diligence to attend the hearing; but
was absent from the hearing because of circumstances beyond the claimant’s control.

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board may fix another date, time and place for hearing the appeal if the Board is satisfied, on the basis of the written explanation and supporting evidence submitted with the request, that the claimant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: had exercised all due diligence to attend the hearing; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was absent from the hearing because of circumstances beyond the claimant’s control.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Chairperson may give directions
section.content: The Chairperson may give directions, generally or in a particular case, on the practice and procedure of the Appeal Board in hearing and determining an appeal, so long as the direction is consistent with Part VIIC.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Appeal Board may determine own procedure
section.content: Subject to Part VIIC and any direction of the Chairperson, the Appeal Board may determine its own procedure in hearing an appeal.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Evidence considered by Appeal Board in an appeal under section 37ZR

subsection.leadIn: In an appeal under section 37ZR, the Appeal Board has the power to review the merits of the case, and accordingly it may consider—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the same evidence that was before an immigration officer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if subsection (2) applies, evidence that was not before an immigration officer.

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board may consider evidence that was not before an immigration officer if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the evidence relates to matters that have occurred after the decision being appealed against was made; or (Amended 7 of 2021 s. 25)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the evidence relates to matters that occurred before the decision being appealed against was made, and the claimant provides sufficient evidence in writing to satisfy the Board that the claimant—

subparagraph.content: had exercised all due diligence to provide the evidence to an immigration officer before the decision was made; but
failed to provide the evidence to an immigration officer before the decision was made because of circumstances beyond the claimant’s control. (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: A claimant who wishes to present any evidence under section 18(2) of this Schedule at a hearing must within 7 days after filing a notice of appeal under section 37ZS (or section 37ZT if late filing is allowed)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: file with the Appeal Board a written notice to that effect; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: serve a copy of the notice on the Director. (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: The written notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: indicate the nature of the evidence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: explain how the evidence supports the torture claim. (Replaced 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: If the evidence falls within the description in section 18(2)(b) of this Schedule, the written notice must also—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state the circumstances leading to the failure referred to in that section;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: explain how, and to what extent, the circumstances led to the failure;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: state the steps that the claimant had taken with a view to providing the evidence to an immigration officer before the decision being appealed against was made and, in particular, the steps taken to deal with the circumstances; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: be accompanied by all available evidence relied on in support of the claimant’s case. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: A written notice filed after the expiry of the period specified in subsection (1) may not be accepted by the Appeal Board unless the claimant provides sufficient evidence in writing to satisfy the Board that the claimant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: had exercised all due diligence to file the notice before the expiry of the period; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: failed to file the notice before the expiry of the period because of circumstances beyond the claimant’s control. (Added 7 of 2021 s. 25)

section.name: s20
section.heading: Evidence considered by Appeal Board in an application for revocation decision
section.leadIn: In an application for a revocation decision under section 37ZM, the Appeal Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has the power to review the merits of the case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may consider any evidence that the Board considers relevant.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Evidence on oath etc.
section.leadIn: For the purposes of sections 18 and 20 of this Schedule, the Appeal Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: administer oaths and affirmations;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: receive and consider any material by way of oral evidence (on oath or otherwise) or written statements or documents (by affidavit or otherwise).

subsection.leadIn: The Appeal Board may, on an application by a party to an appeal, or on its own motion, direct a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to attend as a witness at the hearing of the appeal at the time and place the Board specifies; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at the hearing to answer any questions, to give evidence on oath or otherwise or to produce any document in that person’s possession, custody or power that may relate to any issue in the appeal.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (1), a person must not be compelled to give any evidence or produce any document that the person could not be compelled to give or produce in proceedings in a court of law.

Subsection (2) does not entitle a person to refuse to give any evidence or to produce any document on the ground only that the evidence or document would not be admissible in a court of law and that accordingly the person could not be compelled to give or produce it.
On an appeal against a decision referred to in section 37ZR, the Appeal Board may confirm or reverse the decision.
On an application for a revocation decision under section 37ZM, the Appeal Board may allow or refuse the application.
The Appeal Board must give its decision with reasons in writing.
The Appeal Board’s decision is final.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Record of proceedings
section.content: The Appeal Board must keep a record or summary of proceedings and of its decisions in such form as the Chairperson may determine.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Correction of errors
section.content: The Appeal Board may correct a decision made by it to the extent necessary to rectify an error of translation or transcription or a clerical error.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Privileges and immunities of members and witnesses

subsection.content: In the performance of their functions under Part VIIC, the Chairperson, Deputy Chairperson and other members of the Appeal Board have the same privileges and immunities as a judge of the Court of First Instance in civil proceedings in that court.

A person appearing at a hearing before the Appeal Board as a witness, a party to the appeal or a legal representative of a party to the appeal is entitled to the same privileges and immunities to which the person would be entitled in civil proceedings in the Court of First Instance.

section.name: s1
section.heading: In this Schedule—

def.name: DeportationBritishSubjectsOrdinance,DeportationOfAliensOrdinance,ImmigrationControlAndOffencesOrdinance
def.leadIn: Deportation (British Subjects) Ordinance (《遞解(英籍人士)條例》), Deportation of Aliens Ordinance (《遞解外國人條例》), and Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance (《入境(管制及罪行)條例》) mean respectively—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the repealed Deportation (British Subjects) Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the repealed Deportation of Aliens Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the repealed Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance;

section.def: Immigrants Control Ordinance (《入境者管制條例》) means the Immigrants Control Ordinance (Cap. 243 Revised Edition 1950) repealed by the repealed Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance;

Police Supervision Ordinance (《警方監管條例》) means the Police Supervision Ordinance (Cap. 224, Revised Edition 1972) repealed by the Police Supervision (Repeal) Ordinance 1983 (55 of 1983); (Added 55 of 1983 s. 3)
repealed (廢除), except in relation to the Immigrants Control Ordinance and the Police Supervision Ordinance, means repealed by this Ordinance. (Replaced 55 of 1983 s. 3)

section.name: s2
section.content: Section 4(1)(a) shall have effect as if it included a reference to a person who arrived in Hong Kong before the commencement date, being a person who immediately before the commencement date was being examined or further examined under section 11 of the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance or was about to be so examined or further examined; and the provisions of this Ordinance shall apply to any such person accordingly.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Section 5(4)(a) & (5)(a)
section.content: The references in section 5(4)(a) and 5(5)(a) to an entry permit and a re-entry permit include references to an entry permit and a re-entry permit issued under the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance.

section.name: s4
section.content: Section 9(1)(b) shall have effect as if the references to a person having been refused permission to land in Hong Kong and having been given permission to land in Hong Kong included references to having been refused permission to enter Hong Kong under the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance or the repealed Immigrants Control Ordinance and to having been given permission to enter Hong Kong under either of those Ordinances.

section.name: s5
section.content: Section 10(2) shall have effect as if it included a reference to a serviceman who ceased to be such before the commencement date, being a serviceman who had not made an application under section 38 of the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance before that date or whose application had not been determined under the said Ordinance before that date.

section.name: s6
section.content: Any conditions imposed in respect of a person who entered Hong Kong before the commencement date under section 15 of the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance and in force immediately before that date (whether the same were imposed at the time of entry or subsequent thereto) shall, subject to section 8(2), continue in force and have effect as if they were conditions of stay imposed under section 11(2) of this Ordinance; and the provisions of this Ordinance shall apply accordingly.

section.name: s7
section.content: Section 14(1) shall have effect as if it included a reference to an alien who is in Hong Kong on the commencement date, being an alien who had become liable before that date to comply with section 25(1) of the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance but had not complied therewith.

section.name: s8
section.content: Section 16 shall have effect as if the references to particulars furnished in an arrival card and to particulars furnished in the prescribed form pursuant to section 14(1) include respectively references to corresponding particulars furnished to the Director or to the former immigration officer or to the former Registrar of Aliens in accordance with the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance or the repealed Immigrants Control Ordinance or a requirement made under either of those Ordinances.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Sections 18, 24 & 32(1)
section.content: Sections 18, 24 and 32(1) shall apply to a person, not being a person who has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 8(1), who before the commencement date has been refused permission to enter Hong Kong under the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance as they apply to a person who is refused permission to land under this Ordinance.

section.name: s10
section.content: Section 18(1)(b) shall have effect, except in the case of a person who has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 8(1), as if it included a reference to a condition imposed under section 15 of the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance and in force immediately before the commencement date, being a condition making the same requirement as the condition of stay referred to in the said section 18(1)(b); and the provisions of this Ordinance shall apply accordingly.

section.name: s11
section.content: Section 19(1)(b)(ii) shall have effect as if it included a reference to a person who has contravened section 3(1)(a)(ii) or (b) of the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance or any condition imposed under section 15 of the said Ordinance and in force immediately before the commencement date (whether such condition was imposed at the time of entry or subsequent thereto), but in whose case an order has not been made under section 43(4) of the said Ordinance; and the provisions of this Ordinance shall apply accordingly.

section.name: s12
section.content: Any order made in respect of a person under section 43(4) of the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance, not being a person who has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 8(1), shall, if in force immediately before the commencement date, continue in force and have effect for all purposes of this Ordinance as if it were a removal order made in respect of that person under section 19 of this Ordinance.

section.name: s13
section.content: Any deportation order made against a person under the Deportation (British Subjects) Ordinance or the Deportation of Aliens Ordinance and in force immediately before the commencement date shall continue in force and have effect for all purposes of this Ordinance as if it were a deportation order made under section 20(1) of this Ordinance.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Sections 19(4) & 20(7)
section.leadIn: Sections 19(4) and 20(7) shall have effect as if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the reference to authority to remain in Hong Kong included a reference to a permit of the Director granted under the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Sections 24(2), 25(3) & 33
section.content: A person, not being a person who has the right to land in Hong Kong by virtue of section 8(1), who immediately before the commencement date was on board a ship or aircraft, having been placed thereon with a view to his removal from Hong Kong in accordance with the Immigration (Control and Offences) Ordinance, the Deportation (British Subjects) Ordinance or the Deportation of Aliens Ordinance or any order or requirement made or issued thereunder, shall be deemed to have been placed thereon under section 24(2) or section 25(3), as the case may be, and it shall be presumed that an immigration officer, immigration assistant or police officer has made a requirement under section 33 of this Ordinance; and the provisions of this Ordinance shall apply accordingly.

section.name: s16
